output: imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine
source_instruction: What does Section 251 of Indian Penal Code, 1860 state?

instruction: If a party is dissatisfied with the final decree but not with the preliminary decree, to which court can they appeal according to Section 97?
output: The party can appeal against the final decree as per Section 97 of the Code of Civil Procedure, 1908.
source_instruction: Under which Act does Section 97 titled 'Appeal from final decree where no appeal from preliminary decree' fall?

instruction: If a father is ordered to provide monthly maintenance for his disabled adult child, what happens if he fails to comply?
output: If any person so ordered fails without sufficient cause to comply with the order, any such Magistrate may, for every breach of the order, issue a warrant for levying the amount due in the manner provided for levying fines, and may sentence such person, for the whole, or any part of each month's allowance for the maintenance or the interim maintenance and expenses of proceeding, as the case may be remaining unpaid after the execution of the warrant, to imprisonment for a term which may extend to one month or until payment if sooner made;
source_instruction: What does Section 125 of Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973 state?

instruction: If a wife refuses to live with her husband but later claims she had a legitimate reason for refusing, what can the magistrate do according to Section 125 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973?
output: The magistrate may consider any grounds of refusal stated by her, and may make an order under this section notwithstanding such offer, if he is satisfied that there is just ground for so doing.
source_instruction: What does Section 125 of Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973 state?

instruction: If a minor files a divorce petition, who becomes responsible for the costs and why?
output: The next friend of the minor becomes responsible for the costs. This is because the statute requires the next friend to undertake in writing to be answerable for costs, which means they will be held financially accountable.
source_instruction: Summarize Section 49 of Indian Divorce Act, 1869.

instruction: If an employee intentionally deletes important company records from their computer, can they be charged under Section 477A of the Indian Penal Code?
output: Yes, if the employee was acting in the capacity of a clerk, officer or servant and had access to the company records for work purposes, then they could be charged under Section 477A of the Indian Penal Code as they have destroyed an electronic record with intent to defraud.
source_instruction: Summarize Section 477A of Indian Penal Code, 1860.

instruction: If someone offers money to a witness in exchange for them not reporting a crime they witnessed, which part of Section 214 of the Indian Penal Code, 1860 is violated?
output: Section 214 of the Indian Penal Code, 1860 states that whoever gives or causes, or offers or agrees to give or cause, any gratification to any person, in consideration of that persons concealing an offence, or of his screening any person from legal punishment for any offence, or of his not proceeding against any person for the purpose of bringing him to legal punishment;
source_instruction: What does Section 214 of Indian Penal Code, 1860 state?

instruction: If a warrant needs to be executed in another district, what steps must the issuing court take according to Section 78 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973?
output: The issuing court may forward the warrant by post or otherwise to an Executive Magistrate, District Superintendent of Police, or Commissioner of Police within the local limits where the warrant is to be executed. These officials then endorse their names on the warrant and execute it in the prescribed manner.
source_instruction: What does Section 78 of Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973 state?

instruction: If a suit is filed in one of multiple competent courts, under what condition can a defendant request for transfer of the suit to another court?
output: after notice to the other parties, may, at the earliest possible opportunity and in all cases where issues are settled at or before such settlement, apply to have the suit transferred to another Court
source_instruction: Summarize Section 22 of Code of Civil Procedure, 1908.

instruction: If an accused person appears in a summons case, what must the Magistrate do according to Section 251 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973?
output: The Magistrate must state the particulars of the offence to the accused and ask if he pleads guilty or has any defence to make.
source_instruction: Summarize Section 251 of Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973.

instruction: If an appeal is taken from an order made under the Code of Civil Procedure, 1908, how will the provisions of this part apply?
output: so far as may be, apply to appeals from orders made under this Code
source_instruction: What does Section 108 of Code of Civil Procedure, 1908 state?

instruction: If a tenant's agent commits a riot on behalf of the landlord, under what circumstances can the agent be punished?
output: The agent or manager of the landlord can be punishable with fine if they have reason to believe that the riot was likely to be committed or that the unlawful assembly by which the riot was committed was likely to be held, and they do not use all lawful means in their power to prevent such riot or assembly from taking place and for suppressing and dispersing the same.
source_instruction: Explain Section 156 (Liability of agent of owner or occupier for whose benefit riot is committed) in simple terms.

instruction: If a person helps an escapee from a military prison by providing them with food and shelter, what punishment can they face under Section 130 of the Indian Penal Code, 1860?
output: imprisonment for life, or with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine
source_instruction: Explain Section 130 of the Indian Penal Code, 1860.

instruction: If a person who was previously convicted of forgery (an offense under Chapter XII of the IPC) and sentenced to five years' imprisonment is now accused of another forgery, what should happen according to Section 324 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973?
output: The Magistrate before whom the case is pending shall send the accused for trial to the Chief Judicial Magistrate or commit the case to the Court of Session, unless the Magistrate is competent to try the case and is of opinion that he can himself pass an adequate sentence if the accused is convicted.
source_instruction: Explain Section 324 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973.

instruction: If someone moves an item belonging to another person with the intention of stealing it but changes their mind and returns it before actually taking it, has a theft occurred according to Section 378 of the Indian Penal Code, 1860?
output: No, a theft has not occurred as per Section 378 of the Indian Penal Code, 1860 because the section requires that the property must be taken dishonestly by moving it out of the possession of the person without their consent, which implies the actual taking of the property.
source_instruction: Explain Section 378 of the Indian Penal Code, 1860.

instruction: If a promissory note is payable in three equal installments over one year, when should the first installment be presented for payment according to Section 67?
output: The first installment of the promissory note should be presented for payment on the third day after the date fixed for payment of the first installment.
source_instruction: Explain Section 67 (Presentment for payment of promissory note payable by instalments) in simple terms.

instruction: If John holds a cheque endorsed in blank and writes a direction to pay to Jane instead, what happens according to Section 49 of the Negotiable Instruments Act, 1881?
output: John can convert the indorsement in blank into an indorsement in full by writing a direction to pay to Jane without signing his own name. He does not thereby incur the responsibility of an indorser.
source_instruction: What does Section 49 of Negotiable Instruments Act, 1881 state?

instruction: If a couple applies for a divorce a mensa et toro under the Indian Divorce Act, 1869, what court has jurisdiction?
output: The High Courts have jurisdiction to exercise matrimonial jurisdiction in respect of divorce a mensa et toro.
source_instruction: Explain Section 4 of the Indian Divorce Act, 1869.

instruction: If an agent signs a cheque and does not indicate that they are acting as an agent, what liability do they face according to Section 28 of the Negotiable Instruments Act, 1881?
output: an agent who signs his name to a promissory note, bill of exchange or cheque without indicating thereon that he signs as agent, or that he does not intend thereby to incur personal responsibility, is liable personally on the instrument, except to those who induced him to sign upon the belief that the principal only would be held liable.
source_instruction: Explain Section 28 of the Negotiable Instruments Act, 1881.

instruction: Can a police officer arrest someone without a warrant if they find them carrying a crowbar?
output: Yes, if the person is found to be in possession of a crowbar without a lawful excuse, the police officer can arrest them without a warrant.
source_instruction: Explain Section 41 (When police may arrest without warrant) in simple terms.

instruction: If a witness testifies that a statement made by someone applied to a specific incident involving two groups of people, but the wording is ambiguous between both groups, can the other party introduce evidence to clarify which group the statement referred to?
output: Yes, evidence may be given to show to which of the two sets of facts the statement was meant to apply.
source_instruction: Explain Section 97 of the Indian Evidence Act, 1872.

instruction: If the state government directs that reports should be submitted through a specific police officer, what can that officer do according to Section 158?
output: Such superior officer may give such instructions to the officer in charge of the police station as he thinks fit.
source_instruction: Summarize Section 158 of Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973.

instruction: If a villager notices a person who they believe is involved in selling stolen goods, what should they do according to Section 40 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973?
output: The villager should forthwith communicate to the nearest Magistrate or to the officer in charge of the nearest police station, whichever is nearer, any information they possess regarding the permanent or temporary residence of the person suspected of being a notorious receiver or vendor of stolen property.
source_instruction: Summarize Section 40 of Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973.

instruction: If a decree is for the payment of money, under what circumstances can a court order the debtor to be detained in prison?
output: where the judgment-debtor, with the object or effect of obstructing or delaying the execution of the decree, is likely to abscond or leave the local limits of the jurisdiction of the Court, or has, after the institution of the suit in which the decree was passed, dishonestly transferred, concealed, or removed any part of his property, or committed any other act of bad faith in relation to his property, or that the judgment-debtor has, or has had since the date of the decree, the means to pay the amount of the decree or some substantial part thereof and refuses or neglects or has refused or neglected to pay the same, or that the decree is for a sum for which the judgment-debtor was bound in a fiduciary capacity to account.
source_instruction: Explain Section 51 of the Code of Civil Procedure, 1908.

instruction: If a court issues a summons to a witness who lives in Mumbai but works in Delhi, how should the summons be served according to Section 69 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973?
output: The court may direct a copy of the summons to be served by registered post addressed to the witness at the place where he ordinarily resides or carries on business or personally works for gain. In this case, the court may choose to serve the summons by registered post addressed to the witness at his residence in Mumbai.
source_instruction: Summarize Section 69 of Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973.

instruction: If someone participates in a riot and is found guilty under Section 147, what kind of punishment can they face?
output: imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to two years, or with fine, or with both
source_instruction: Explain Section 147 (Punishment for rioting) in simple terms.

instruction: If a couple wants to get married under the Hindu Marriage Act, 1955, can their second cousins marry? Explain your answer based on the definition of 'degrees of prohibited relationship'.
output: No, their second cousins cannot marry. According to the statute, two persons are within the degrees of prohibited relationship if they are siblings, uncles and nieces, aunts and nephews, or children of siblings or two brothers or two sisters. Second cousins do not fall into any of these categories.
source_instruction: Explain Section 3 (Definitions.) in simple terms.

instruction: If an accused person wants to call a witness to testify on their behalf, what steps must they follow according to Section 243?
output: The accused must first enter into their defense and produce their evidence. Afterward, they can apply to the Magistrate to issue a process for compelling the attendance of any witness for examination or cross-examination, or the production of any document or other thing. However, the Magistrate may refuse the application if it is made for the purpose of vexation, delay, or defeating the ends of justice.
source_instruction: Explain Section 243 (Evidence for defence) in simple terms.

instruction: If a parent gives their child's consent for them to travel abroad, can someone still be charged under Section 360 of the Indian Penal Code, 1860?
output: Yes, if the child did not give their own consent and the parent was not authorized to give consent on behalf of the child, then the person conveying the child beyond the limits of India could be charged under Section 360.
source_instruction: Explain Section 360 of the Indian Penal Code, 1860.

instruction: If a person is sentenced under Section 344 and wants to appeal, to which court can they appeal?
output: The person can appeal to the Court to which decrees or orders made in such Court are ordinarily appealable.
source_instruction: Summarize Section 351 of Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973.

instruction: If a High Court makes a decree for dissolution of marriage and sets the period for its absoluteness to 7 months, how long can collusion be raised as a ground for setting aside the decree?
output: During that period any person shall be at liberty, in such manner as the High Co
source_instruction: Summarize Section 16 of Indian Divorce Act, 1869.

instruction: If John transfers a cheque to Jane and she later becomes a holder in due course, what can we infer about the liability of John under Section 36 of the Negotiable Instruments Act, 1881?
output: Every prior party to a negotiable instrument, including John, is liable thereon to a holder in due course like Jane until the instrument is duly satisfied.
source_instruction: Explain Section 36 (Liability of prior parties to holder in due course) in simple terms.

instruction: If a person stops at the scene of an accident to help an injured individual and accidentally causes further harm due to their negligence, can they be held legally responsible under normal circumstances?
output: No, under Section 134A of the Motor Vehicles Act, 1988, a Good Samaritan is not liable for any civil or criminal action for any injury to or death of the victim of an accident involving a motor vehicle if such injury or death resulted from the Good Samaritan's negligence in acting or failing to act while rendering emergency medical or non-medical care or assistance.
source_instruction: What does Section 134A of Motor Vehicles Act, 1988 state?

instruction: If a High Court refers a question to itself under Section 396, what is required for the referring court?
output: The referring court shall dispose of the case conformably to the order passed by the High Court.
source_instruction: What does Section 396 of Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973 state?

instruction: If a defendant claims they did not have the intent to commit theft, can evidence of their prior conversations showing planning and preparation for the theft be considered relevant under Section 14?
output: Yes, evidence of the defendant's prior conversations showing planning and preparation for the theft can be considered relevant under Section 14 as it shows the existence of the state of mind (intention) which was in issue.
source_instruction: Explain Section 14 (Facts showing existence of state of mind, or of body or bodily feeling) in simple terms.

instruction: If someone locks another person inside their house without permission and prevents them from leaving, does this action fall under wrongful restraint according to Section 339?
output: Yes, if someone locks another person inside their house without permission and prevents them from leaving, they are voluntarily obstructing that person from proceeding in a direction where they have a right to go, thus falling under wrongful restraint as defined in Section 339.
source_instruction: Explain Section 339 (Wrongful restraint) in simple terms.

instruction: If a state government wants to change the magistrate handling certain types of cases from an Executive Magistrate to a Judicial Magistrate of the first class, what is required according to Section 478 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973?
output: The State Government can make such a direction only if the Legislative Assembly of the State permits it by a resolution and after consulting the High Court.
source_instruction: Explain Section 478 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973.

instruction: If a driver is convicted of a traffic offense and given a sentence of more than three months in prison, what action must the court take regarding their driving license?
output: The Court shall endorse the fact of such sentence upon the driving license of the person concerned.
source_instruction: Explain Section 24 of the Motor Vehicles Act, 1988.

instruction: If three judges hear an appeal and two of them want to reverse the original decision while the third wants to affirm it, what happens according to Section 98?
output: The appeal shall be decided in accordance with the opinion of the majority, which in this case would be the two judges wanting to reverse the original decision.
source_instruction: Explain Section 98 of the Code of Civil Procedure, 1908.

instruction: If a cheque is marked 'ABC Co.' between two parallel lines, how should it be treated according to the Negotiable Instruments Act, 1881?
output: That addition shall be deemed a crossing, and the cheque shall be deemed to be crossed generally.
source_instruction: What does Section 123 of Negotiable Instruments Act, 1881 state?

instruction: What can the Central Government do if there is a difficulty in implementing the Motor Vehicles Act, 1988?
output: The Central Government can make such provisions, not inconsistent with the provisions of the Act, as appear to it to be necessary or expedient for removing the difficulty.
source_instruction: Explain Section 216 of the Motor Vehicles Act, 1988.

instruction: If a person is charged with theft under Section 378 of the Indian Penal Code (IPC), how should the term 'theft' be interpreted according to Section 214 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973?
output: The term 'theft' in the charge should be deemed to have been used in the sense attached to it by the Indian Penal Code (IPC) under which theft is punishable.
source_instruction: Summarize Section 214 of Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973.

instruction: If a company applies for a goods carriage permit and specifies a route within a state, what can the Regional Transport Authority do according to Section 79 of the Motor Vehicles Act, 1988?
output: The Regional Transport Authority may grant the goods carriage permit and attach conditions to it, including specifying the area or route where the vehicle can operate, limiting the gross vehicle weight, prohibiting certain types of goods, setting rates for carrying goods, requiring arrangements for housing, maintenance, and repair of the vehicle, and demanding periodic returns and information.
source_instruction: What does Section 79 of Motor Vehicles Act, 1988 state?

instruction: If a cheque is endorsed in blank and then crossed, who can present it for payment?
output: A negotiable instrument indorsed in blank is payable to the bearer thereof even though originally payable to order. Therefore, if a cheque is endorsed in blank and then crossed, it remains payable to the bearer.
source_instruction: Explain Section 54 of the Negotiable Instruments Act, 1881.

instruction: If a complainant has to travel from another state to testify in a case under the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973, can the court order the government to pay their travel expenses?
output: Yes, subject to any rules made by the State Government, any Criminal Court may order payment, on the part of Government, of the reasonable expenses of any complainant or witness attending for the purposes of any inquiry, trial or other proceeding before such Court under this Code.
source_instruction: Summarize Section 312 of Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973.

instruction: If a police officer receives an anonymous tip about someone planning to commit a serious crime like murder, what should they do according to Section 150?
output: Every police officer receiving information of a design to commit any cognizable offence shall communicate such information to the police officer to whom he is subordinate, and to any other officer whose duty it is to prevent or take cognizance of the commission of any such offence.
source_instruction: Explain Section 150 (Information of design to commit cognizable offences) in simple terms.

instruction: If someone is found guilty of collecting weapons with the intent to rebel against the government, what kind of punishment can they face according to Section 122?
output: imprisonment for life or imprisonment of either description for a term not exceeding ten years, and shall also be liable to fine
source_instruction: Explain Section 122 (Collecting arms, etc., with intention of waging war against the Government of India) in simple terms.

instruction: If someone plans to attack a government building but later decides to abandon the plan, what punishment can they face under Section 121A?
output: imprisonment for life, or with imprisonment of either description which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.
source_instruction: Explain Section 121A of the Indian Penal Code, 1860.

instruction: If someone breaks into my house and tries to steal something, can I use force to stop them?
output: Yes, you have the right to defend your property against an act that falls under the definition of theft or criminal trespass. You can use force to prevent the theft.
source_instruction: Explain Section 97 (Right of private defence of the body and of property) in simple terms.

instruction: If a person applies for a driving license and fails the test, how many times can they attempt the test before needing to complete a remedial training course?
output: The applicant may be permitted to re-appear for the test after a period of seven days. However, if the applicant does not pass the test even after three appearances, he shall not be qualified to re-appear for such test before the expiry of a period of sixty days from the date of last such test and such applicant shall be required to complete a remedial driver training course from any school or establishment under section 12.
source_instruction: Explain Section 9 (Grant of driving licence) in simple terms.

instruction: If a person passes a test on a motor cycle with gear, can they automatically drive a motor cycle without gear?
output: Yes, a person who passed a test in driving a motor cycle with gear shall be deemed also to have passed a test in driving a motor cycle without gear.
source_instruction: Explain Section 9 (Grant of driving licence) in simple terms.

instruction: If the state government has fixed the scale of monthly allowances for a judgment-debtor who is an Indian national but not a high-ranking official, what would be the likely allowance based on the given statute?
output: Based on the statute text, the state government can fix scales of monthly allowances 'graduated according to rank, race and nationality'. Since the judgment-debtor is an Indian national but not a high-ranking official, the allowance would likely be at a level corresponding to the nationality criterion rather than the rank criterion.
source_instruction: Summarize Section 57 of Code of Civil Procedure, 1908.

instruction: If a person hides evidence of a planned theft and later claims they did not know the crime was going to happen, can they be charged under Section 120 of the Indian Penal Code, 1860?
output: Yes, if the person knew it was likely their actions would facilitate the commission of the theft, they could be charged under Section 120 of the Indian Penal Code, 1860 as they have concealed the existence of a design to commit an offence.
source_instruction: What does Section 120 of Indian Penal Code, 1860 state?

instruction: If a vehicle's registration was suspended for 7 months, can the registering authority cancel its registration?
output: Yes, because the suspension of registration has continued without interruption for a period of not less than six months.
source_instruction: Explain Section 54 (Cancellation of registration suspended under section 53) in simple terms.

instruction: If someone claims they did not steal an item because they had never stolen anything before, how can the existence of a regular practice within their organization influence this claim?
output: The existence of a regular practice within the organization where such thefts occur, according to which items might have been taken, could be considered a relevant fact in determining whether the specific act of taking the item was done as part of that practice.
source_instruction: Summarize Section 16 of Indian Evidence Act, 1872.

instruction: If a Metropolitan Magistrate's decision is challenged by the High Court, what should they provide?
output: The Magistrate may submit with the record a statement setting forth the grounds of his decision or order and any facts which he thinks material to the issue.
source_instruction: Summarize Section 404 of Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973.

instruction: If a plaintiff's character affects the amount of damages they should receive, what kind of evidence can be presented in court?
output: The fact that the plaintiff's character is such as to affect the amount of damages which he ought to receive is relevant.
source_instruction: Summarize Section 55 of Indian Evidence Act, 1872.

instruction: If an order cannot be served directly to the person against whom it is made, how should it be communicated?
output: It should be notified by proclamation, published in such manner as the State Government may, by rules, direct, and a copy thereof shall be stuck up at such place or places as may be fittest for conveying the information to such person.
source_instruction: Explain Section 134 (Service or notification of order) in simple terms.

instruction: If a party fails to raise an objection regarding the court's jurisdiction in the original trial court, can they raise it on appeal?
output: No, if the objection regarding the court's jurisdiction is not raised in the Court of first instance at the earliest possible opportunity, it cannot be raised in any Appellate or Revisional Court.
source_instruction: Summarize Section 21 of Code of Civil Procedure, 1908.

instruction: If a person is found guilty of creating a public nuisance and continues to do so despite being warned, what action can an Executive Magistrate take under Section 143 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973?
output: An Executive Magistrate may order such a person not to repeat or continue the public nuisance.
source_instruction: Summarize Section 143 of Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973.

instruction: Can a person provide evidence from an internal audit report of the Income Tax Department without obtaining permission?
output: No, a person cannot provide evidence from an unpublished official record related to the affairs of the Income Tax Department without the permission of the officer at the head of the department.
source_instruction: What does Section 123 of Indian Evidence Act, 1872 state?

instruction: If a case is brought to a magistrate's court based on a complaint and the complainant fails to appear on the scheduled hearing date, what can the magistrate do according to Section 249 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973?
output: The magistrate may, in his discretion, at any time before the charge has been framed, discharge the accused.
source_instruction: What does Section 249 of Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973 state?

instruction: If a civil court passes a decree and sends it to another district for execution, what happens according to Section 38?
output: The decree can be executed by the Court to which it is sent for execution.
source_instruction: Explain Section 38 (Court by which decree may be executed) in simple terms.

instruction: Can the court assume that a message sent through a telegraph office is identical to the one received?
output: Yes, the court may presume that a message, forwarded from a telegraph office to the person to whom such message purports to be addressed, corresponds with a message delivered for transmission at the office from which the message purports to be sent.
source_instruction: What does Section 88 of Indian Evidence Act, 1872 state?

instruction: Can a suspect who committed a non-bailable offense and was arrested without a warrant be released on bail if there are reasonable grounds to believe they have committed another crime?
output: such person shall not be so released if there appear reasonable grounds for believing that he has been
source_instruction: Summarize Section 437 of Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973.

instruction: If a person is convicted of an offense carrying a maximum sentence of 10 years' imprisonment and also a fine, how long can they be imprisoned for non-payment of the fine according to Section 65?
output: The term for which the Court directs the offender to be imprisoned in default of payment of a fine shall not exceed one-fourth of the term of imprisonment which is the maximum fixed for the offence, if the offence be punishable with imprisonment as well as fine. Therefore, in this case, the maximum term of imprisonment for non-payment of the fine would be 2.5 years (one-fourth of 10 years).
source_instruction: Explain Section 65 (Limit to imprisonment for non-payment of fine, when imprisonment and fine awardable) in simple terms.

instruction: If an accused person does not have enough money to hire a lawyer during a trial in the Court of Session, what action can the court take according to Section 304 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973?
output: The Court shall assign a pleader for his defence at the expense of the State.
source_instruction: Summarize Section 304 of Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973.

instruction: If a magistrate receives information and decides to require a suspect to show cause, what details must be included in the order?
output: The order must set forth the substance of the information received, the amount of the bond to be executed, the term for which it is to be in force, and the number, character and class of sureties (if any) required.
source_instruction: Explain Section 111 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973.

instruction: If a person receives a telegram claiming they owe money, can the court assume the telegram was sent by someone who owes money?
output: No, the court cannot assume the telegram was sent by someone who owes money. The statute only allows the court to presume that the message received matches the one delivered for transmission, not the identity of the sender.
source_instruction: Explain Section 88 of the Indian Evidence Act, 1872.

instruction: Can the defense introduce evidence of the defendant's good character to prove innocence in a criminal case under the Indian Evidence Act, 1872?
output: Yes, the fact that the person accused is of a good character is relevant in criminal proceedings.
source_instruction: What does Section 53 of Indian Evidence Act, 1872 state?

instruction: If a civil surgeon provides a deposition in an inquiry, can the accused later challenge this testimony during a trial?
output: Yes, the Court may summon and examine any deponent, including a civil surgeon, as to the subject-matter of their deposition, upon application by either the prosecution or the accused.
source_instruction: Explain Section 291 (Deposition of medical witness) in simple terms.

instruction: If a plaintiff's suit is dismissed and the court finds that the previous attachment was made without sufficient grounds, what action can the court take?
output: Where, in any suit in which an arrest or attachment has been effected or a temporary injunction granted under the last preceding section, (a) it appears to the Court that such arrest, attachment or injunction was applied for on insufficient grounds, or (b) the suit of the plaintiff fails and it appears to the Court that there was no reasonable or probable grounds for instituting the same, the Court may make such order as it thinks fit for the removal of the arrest, attachment or injunction.
source_instruction: Summarize Section 95 of Code of Civil Procedure, 1908.

instruction: If someone is caught stealing goods worth Rs. 5000, what kind of punishment can they face according to Section 379 of the Indian Penal Code, 1860?
output: imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to three years, or with fine, or with both
source_instruction: What does Section 379 of Indian Penal Code, 1860 state?

instruction: If a witness falsely states under oath that they saw a crime occur when they did not see it happen, what punishment can they face according to Section 181 of the Indian Penal Code, 1860?
output: whoever, being legally bound by an oath or affirmation to state the truth on any subject to any public servant or other person authorized by law to administer such oath or affirmation, makes, to such public servant or other person as aforesaid, touching that subject, any statement which is false, and which he either knows or believes to be false or does not believe to be true, shall be punished
source_instruction: Summarize Section 181 of Indian Penal Code, 1860.

instruction: If a person fails to appear after being summoned, what can the court do according to Section 32 of the Code of Civil Procedure, 1908?
output: The court may order him to furnish security for his appearance and in default commit him to the civil prison.
source_instruction: What does Section 32 of Code of Civil Procedure, 1908 state?

instruction: If the District Magistrate's position becomes vacant, who can take over the responsibilities?
output: Whenever, in consequence of the office of a District Magistrate becoming Vacant, any officer succeeds temporarily to the executive administration of the district, such officer shall, pending the orders of the State Government, exercise all the powers and perform all the duties respectively conferred and imposed by this Code on the District Magistrate.
source_instruction: What does Section 20 of Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973 state?

instruction: Can a 17-year-old apply for a conductor's license?
output: No, a person under the age of eighteen years shall not hold, or be granted, a conductor's license.
source_instruction: What does Section 31 of Motor Vehicles Act, 1988 state?

instruction: If someone uses a knife to stab another person and causes grievous hurt, what punishment can they face under Section 326 of the Indian Penal Code, 1860?
output: imprisonment for life, or with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.
source_instruction: Explain Section 326 of the Indian Penal Code, 1860.

instruction: If a separated wife acquires property during her separation and later remarries, what happens to this property?
output: If a separated wife acquires property during her separation and later remarry, all such property as she may be entitled to when such cohabitation takes place shall be held to her separate use, subject, however, to any agreement in writing made between herself and her husband whilst separate.
source_instruction: Explain Section 24 (Separated wife deemed spinster with respect to after-acquired property) in simple terms.

instruction: If a driver sees an ambulance approaching and does not move their car to the side of the road, what punishment can they face under Section 194E of the Motor Vehicles Act, 1988?
output: With imprisonment for a term which may extend to six months, or with a fine of ten thousand rupees, or with both.
source_instruction: Explain Section 194E of the Motor Vehicles Act, 1988.

instruction: Can an appeal be filed against an order under Section 95 according to Section 104 of the Code of Civil Procedure, 1908?
output: Yes, an appeal can be filed against an order under Section 95 according to Section 104 of the Code of Civil Procedure, 1908.
source_instruction: What does Section 104 of Code of Civil Procedure, 1908 state?

instruction: If a court finds it necessary to adjourn a trial involving offenses under Sections 376 of the Indian Penal Code, how long can the adjournment last?
output: The adjournment can last for such time as the court considers reasonable, but no Magistrate shall remand an accused person to custody for a term exceeding fifteen days at a time.
source_instruction: Explain Section 309 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973.

instruction: If an English minister declines to conduct a marriage ceremony in his church due to personal beliefs, what can another minister do according to Section 59?
output: another minister in holy orders of the said Church, entitled to officiate within the diocese in which such Church or Chapel is situate, to perform such marriage-service in such Church or Chapel
source_instruction: Explain Section 59 (English Minister refusing to perform ceremony to permit use of his Church) in simple terms.

instruction: If a police officer investigates an offense under Sections 376 to 376E of the Indian Penal Code and completes the investigation within the required time frame, what should they do next?
output: The officer in charge of the police station shall forward to a Magistrate empowered to take cognizance of the offence on a police report, a report in the form prescribed by the State Government.
source_instruction: Explain Section 173 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973.

instruction: If a court sentences someone to death, what must happen before the sentence can be carried out?
output: The sentence shall not be executed unless it is confirmed by the High Court.
source_instruction: Summarize Section 366 of Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973.

instruction: What does this act cover according to the given text?
output: The Indian Penal Code, 1860 covers the whole of India except the State of Jammu and Kashmir.
source_instruction: Summarize Section 1 of Indian Penal Code, 1860.

instruction: If a car is being driven by a dealer who possesses it under certain conditions set by the government, which part of Section 39 of the Motor Vehicles Act, 1988 allows this?
output: Provided that nothing in this section shall apply to a motor vehicle in possession of a dealer subject to such conditions as may be prescribed by the Central Government.
source_instruction: What does Section 39 of Motor Vehicles Act, 1988 state?

instruction: If a person resists the lawful authority of a police officer while the officer is trying to take away stolen goods, what punishment can they face according to Section 183 of the Indian Penal Code, 1860?
output: With imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to six months, or with fine which may extend to one thousand rupees, or with both.
source_instruction: Explain Section 183 of the Indian Penal Code, 1860.

instruction: If a person purchases a used car from a private seller, who should make the application for registration?
output: An application by or on behalf of the owner of a motor vehicle for registration shall be in such form and shall be accompanied by such documents, particulars and information and shall be made within such period as may be prescribed by the Central Government:
source_instruction: Explain Section 41 of the Motor Vehicles Act, 1988.

instruction: If a car owner wants to renew their vehicle's registration certificate, what details must they provide in their application?
output: An application for the renewal of a certificate of registration shall be made within such period and in such form, containing such particulars and information as may be prescribed by the Central Government.
source_instruction: Explain Section 41 of the Motor Vehicles Act, 1988.

instruction: If a judge decides to defer the cross-examination of a witness, what can they do according to Section 231?
output: The Judge may, in his discretion, permit the cross-examination of any witness to be deferred until any other witness or witnesses have been examined or recall any witness for further cross-examination.
source_instruction: Explain Section 231 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973.

instruction: If a person appears before a court and is required to appear in another court for trial, what can the officer do under Section 88 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973?
output: The officer may require such person to execute a bond, with or without sureties, for his appearance in such Court, or any other Court to which the case may be transferred for trial.
source_instruction: What does Section 88 of Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973 state?

instruction: If someone leaves their trash on a public sidewalk, causing inconvenience to passersby, can they be charged under Section 268 of the Indian Penal Code, 1860?
output: Yes, if leaving the trash causes any common injury, danger or annoyance to the public or people occupying nearby properties, then the person could be considered guilty of a public nuisance under Section 268 of the Indian Penal Code, 1860.
source_instruction: What does Section 268 of Indian Penal Code, 1860 state?

instruction: If a child aged 9 performs an act that could be considered harmful but was done without understanding its consequences, can they be held criminally responsible?
output: No, the child cannot be held criminally responsible as per Section 83 of the Indian Penal Code, 1860. The section states that nothing is an offence which is done by a child above seven years of age and under twelve, who has not attained sufficient maturity or understanding to judge the nature and consequences of his conduct on that occasion.
source_instruction: Explain Section 83 (Act of a child above seven and under twelve of immature understanding) in simple terms.

instruction: If a contractor fails to secure a building under repair and someone dies due to its collapse, what punishment can they face according to Section 288 of the Indian Penal Code, 1860?
output: imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to six months, or with fine which may extend to one thousand rupees
source_instruction: Summarize Section 288 of Indian Penal Code, 1860.

instruction: If a cheque is drawn on Bank X and the relationship between the drawer and Bank X changes to the drawer's disadvantage due to a new agreement, does the drawer still need to present the cheque to Bank X?
output: No, if the relationship between the drawer and Bank X has been altered to the prejudice of the drawer, then the cheque does not need to be presented to Bank X.
source_instruction: Explain Section 72 (Presentment of cheque to charge drawer) in simple terms.

instruction: If a company applies for a renewal of their permit 10 days before it expires, will their application be accepted?
output: No, the application for the renewal of a permit may be made not less than fifteen days before the date of its expiry.
source_instruction: Explain Section 81 (Duration and renewal of permits) in simple terms.

instruction: If one party requests an assessor in a salvage case but the other party does not agree, what can happen according to Section 140?
output: The Court may summon two competent assessors if it thinks fit, even over the objection of one party.
source_instruction: Explain Section 140 (Assessors in causes of salvage, etc) in simple terms.

instruction: If a person is found guilty of rioting under Section 147 of the Indian Penal Code, what kind of punishment can they face?
output: imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to two years, or with fine, or with both
source_instruction: Explain Section 147 of the Indian Penal Code, 1860.

instruction: If a married woman commits suicide after being subjected to cruelty by her husband for five years, can the court presume that her husband abetted her suicide under Section 113A?
output: Yes, if the wife committed suicide within seven years of her marriage and was subjected to cruelty by her husband during that period, the court may presume that her husband abetted her suicide.
source_instruction: Explain Section 113A (Presumption as to abetment of suicide by a married woman) in simple terms.

instruction: Can a foreign state sue for a private right held by its ruler in an Indian court under the Code of Civil Procedure, 1908?
output: Yes, a foreign State may sue in any competent Court if the object of the suit is to enforce a private right vested in the Ruler of such State.
source_instruction: What does Section 84 of Code of Civil Procedure, 1908 state?

instruction: If a person who has accepted a bill of exchange later sues the holder in due course, can they deny the original validity of the bill?
output: No, a person who has accepted a bill of exchange cannot deny the original validity of the bill in a suit brought by a holder in due course.
source_instruction: Explain Section 120 of the Negotiable Instruments Act, 1881.

instruction: If a bill of exchange from another country is presented for payment, what can we assume about its laws governing it?
output: The laws governing the bill of exchange from the foreign country will be assumed to be the same as those in India, unless proven otherwise.
source_instruction: Explain Section 137 (Presumption as to foreign law) in simple terms.

instruction: If a driver is convicted of an offense under Section 183 for the third time, what can the court do according to Section 20 of the Motor Vehicles Act, 1988?
output: The court may declare the person so convicted to be disqualified, for such period as the Court may specify, from holding any driving licence to drive all classes or description of vehicles, or any particular class or description of such vehicles, as are specified in such licence.
source_instruction: Explain Section 20 of the Motor Vehicles Act, 1988.

instruction: If an officer executes a sentence and returns the warrant without any certification, what might happen according to the statute?
output: The officer executing the sentence shall return the warrant to the Court from which it is issued, with an endorsement under his hand certifying the manner in which the sentence has been executed.
source_instruction: What does Section 430 of Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973 state?

instruction: If a person is caught driving a motorcycle without wearing a helmet, which is against the safety measures under Section 128, what penalty will they face according to Section 194C?
output: He shall be punishable with a fine of one thousand rupees and he shall be disqualified for holding licence for a period of three months.
source_instruction: Explain Section 194C of the Motor Vehicles Act, 1988.

instruction: If a witness owns a piece of land and is not a party to a lawsuit, can they be forced to show the title deed for that land during the trial?
output: No, a witness who is not a party to a suit shall not be compelled to produce his title-deeds to any property unless he has agreed in writing to produce them.
source_instruction: What does Section 130 of Indian Evidence Act, 1872 state?

instruction: What action can a Magistrate of the first class take if they believe it is necessary for an investigation?
output: a Magistrate of the first class may make an order directing any person, including an accused person, to give specimen signatures or handwriting.
source_instruction: Summarize Section 311A of Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973.

instruction: What action is required from the High Court when submitting a case involving a death sentence to them for confirmation?
output: The proper officer of the High Court shall, without delay, after the order of confirmation or other order has been made by the High Court, send a copy of the order under the seal of the High Court and attested with his official signature, to the Court of Session.
source_instruction: Explain Section 371 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973.

instruction: If a magistrate receives an accused person who appeared in response to a warrant case initiated from a police report, what action must the magistrate take according to Section 238 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973?
output: The magistrate shall satisfy himself that he has complied with the provisions of section 207.
source_instruction: What does Section 238 of Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973 state?

instruction: If a cheque is dishonoured on Monday and the holder lives in a different city than the bank where the cheque was presented for payment, when should the holder send the notice of dishonour?
output: The holder should send the notice of dishonour within a reasonable time, which means either by the next post or on the day next after the day of dishonour, i.e., Tuesday.
source_instruction: Explain Section 106 of the Negotiable Instruments Act, 1881.

instruction: Can a police officer arrest someone based solely on a reasonable suspicion of theft without needing a warrant?
output: Yes, a police officer can arrest any person who has been reasonably suspected of possessing stolen property without a warrant.
source_instruction: What does Section 41 of Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973 state?

instruction: If a person is acquitted of murder but the court finds he did indeed kill someone, what can the court do according to Section 335?
output: The court can order such person to be detained in safe custody in such place and manner as the Magistrate or Court thinks fit.
source_instruction: Explain Section 335 (Person acquitted on such ground to be detained in safe custody) in simple terms.

instruction: If a court is trying to dispose of a case under Chapter H of the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973, what powers can it exercise?
output: The court can exercise all the powers vested in respect of bail, trial of offences and other matters relating to the disposal of a case in such Court under this Code.
source_instruction: Summarize Section 265H of Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973.

instruction: If a notification is published in the Official Gazette stating that a certain area was ceded to a Native State on a specific date, can this be used as evidence in court?
output: Yes, if the notification in the Official Gazette states that a particular area was ceded to a Native State on a given date, then this notification will be considered conclusive proof that such a cession occurred on that date.
source_instruction: What does Section 113 of Indian Evidence Act, 1872 state?

instruction: If someone takes their friend's laptop without permission and uses it for personal gain, what punishment can they face under Section 403?
output: imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to two years, or with fine, or with both
source_instruction: Explain Section 403 (Dishonest misappropriation of property) in simple terms.

instruction: If a party produces a certified copy of a foreign judgment in an Indian court under Section 14 of the Code of Civil Procedure, 1908, what is the initial assumption made by the court regarding the judgment's validity?
output: The court shall initially presume that the foreign judgment was pronounced by a Court of competent jurisdiction.
source_instruction: What does Section 14 of Code of Civil Procedure, 1908 state?

instruction: If an officer in charge of a police station receives information about a cognizable offense likely to occur, what action is he required to take according to Section 149?
output: The officer in charge of a police station is required to take steps to prevent the cognizable offence as per Section 149 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973.
source_instruction: Under which Act does Section 149 titled 'Police to prevent cognizable offences' fall?

instruction: If a judge issues a summons without signing it, is it still valid according to Section 61 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973?
output: No, every summons issued by a Court under this Code shall be in writing, in duplicate, signed by the presiding officer of such Court or by such other officer as the High Court may, from time to time, by rule direct.
source_instruction: What does Section 61 of Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973 state?

instruction: If a judge decides to defer the cross-examination of a witness, what can they do according to Section 231 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973?
output: The Judge may, in his discretion, permit the cross-examination of any witness to be deferred until any other witness or witnesses have been examined or recall any witness for further cross-examination.
source_instruction: What does Section 231 of Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973 state?

instruction: If an accused was detained for 60 days during the investigation of a case before being convicted, and is then sentenced to 1 year in prison, how much time will they spend in jail?
output: The period of detention undergone by the accused (60 days) can be set off against the term of imprisonment imposed (1 year). Therefore, the accused will spend 360 days less 60 days = 300 days in jail.
source_instruction: Summarize Section 428 of Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973.

instruction: If an appeal is not dismissed summarily, what procedure should be followed according to the given section?
output: The procedure for hearing appeals not dismissed summarily falls under the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973.
source_instruction: Under which Act does Section 385 titled 'Procedure for hearing appeals not dismissed summarily' fall?

instruction: If John owns a car and his friend drives it without having a valid driving license, what could happen according to Section 5 of the Motor Vehicles Act, 1988?
output: John could be held responsible as he is the owner of the motor vehicle and has allowed someone who does not satisfy the provisions of section 3 (which likely relates to licensing requirements) to drive the vehicle.
source_instruction: Explain Section 5 (Responsibility of owners of motor vehicles for contravention of sections 3 and 4) in simple terms.

instruction: If a person is summoned under Section 138 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973 and shows cause why certain actions should not be taken against them, what procedure is followed?
output: The procedure for when a person appears to show cause why certain actions should not be taken against them is specified in Section 138 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973.
source_instruction: Under which Act does Section 138 titled 'Procedure where he appears to show cause' fall?

instruction: If a decree was originally passed by the District Court and later an area under its jurisdiction is transferred to another court, who can execute the decree?
output: The District Court continues to have jurisdiction to execute the decree, even after the transfer of the area to another court. Additionally, the other court would also have jurisdiction to execute the decree if it had jurisdiction to try the suit at the time of making the application for execution.
source_instruction: What does Section 37 of Code of Civil Procedure, 1908 state?

instruction: If a police officer is accused of an offense related to their official duties, which government's sanction is needed for a court to take cognizance of the offense?
output: in the case of a person who is employed or, as the case may be, was at the time of commission of the alleged offence employed, in connection with the affairs of a State, of the State Government
source_instruction: What does Section 197 of Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973 state?

instruction: If a husband files for divorce on grounds of his wife's adultery, can he testify about the adultery himself?
output: Yes, the husband is competent and compellable to give evidence of or relating to such adultery.
source_instruction: Summarize Section 52 of Indian Divorce Act, 1869.

instruction: If a witness knowingly provides false testimony under oath during a trial, what punishment can they face according to Section 181 of the Indian Penal Code, 1860?
output: He shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to three years, and shall also be liable to fine.
source_instruction: Explain Section 181 of the Indian Penal Code, 1860.

instruction: What details must be included in the State Register of Driving Licences according to Section 26?
output: The State Register of Driving Licences must contain particulars including names and addresses of holders of driving licences, licence numbers, dates of issue or renewal of licences, dates of expiry of licences, classes and types of vehicles authorised to be driven, and such other particulars as the Central Government may prescribe.
source_instruction: Explain Section 26 (Maintenance of State Registers of Driving Licences) in simple terms.

instruction: If a person is found guilty of assaulting a woman with the intent to compel her to remove clothing, what kind of punishment can they face according to Section 354B of the Indian Penal Code, 1860?
output: imprisonment of either description for a term which shall not be less than three years but which may extend to seven years, and shall also be liable to fine
source_instruction: What does Section 354B of Indian Penal Code, 1860 state?

instruction: If a warrant needs to be executed in a different district from where it was issued, what steps should the police officer follow according to Section 79?
output: The police officer should take the warrant for endorsement either to an Executive Magistrate or to a police officer not below the rank of an officer in charge of a police station, within the local limits of whose jurisdiction the warrant is to be executed. Such Magistrate or police officer shall endorse their name on the warrant, and such endorsement shall be sufficient authority to the police officer to whom the warrant is directed to execute the same. If there is a reason to believe that the delay caused by obtaining the endorsement will prevent the execution, the police officer can execute the warrant without such endorsement in any place beyond the local jurisdiction of the Court which issued it.
source_instruction: Explain Section 79 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973.

instruction: What does the term 'property mark' refer to according to Section 479 of the Indian Penal Code, 1860?
output: A mark used for denoting that movable property belongs to a particular person.
source_instruction: Summarize Section 479 of Indian Penal Code, 1860.

instruction: If a wife files a petition for expenses of the proceedings and alimony pending the suit, what can the court do if it is satisfied with her claims?
output: The Court, on being satisfied of the truth of the statements therein contained, may make such order on the husband for payment to the wife of the expenses of the proceedings and alimony pending the suit as it may deem just.
source_instruction: What does Section 36 of Indian Divorce Act, 1869 state?

instruction: If a person is found drunk in a park and causing disturbances, what punishment can they face under Section 510 of the Indian Penal Code, 1860?
output: simple imprisonment for a term which may extend to twenty-four hours, or with fine which may extend to ten rupees, or with both
source_instruction: Explain Section 510 of the Indian Penal Code, 1860.

instruction: If a person signs and acknowledges a will in front of witnesses, can they later deny having signed it?
output: No, if a person admits to signing and acknowledging a will in front of witnesses, it is considered sufficient proof of its execution against them, even if the will needs to be attested by witnesses according to the law.
source_instruction: Summarize Section 70 of Indian Evidence Act, 1872.

instruction: If a 17-year-old girl is taken away by someone without her parents' permission, does this action fall under kidnapping from lawful guardianship according to Section 361?
output: Yes, because the section applies to taking or enticing any minor under eighteen years of age, and a 17-year-old girl falls within this age range.
source_instruction: Explain Section 361 (Kidnapping from lawful guardianship) in simple terms.

instruction: If a state government has already imposed a sentence of death under section 432, can the central government still exercise its power to do so?
output: Yes, in the case of sentences of death, the powers conferred on the state government by sections 432 and 433 can also be exercised by the central government.
source_instruction: Summarize Section 434 of Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973.

instruction: If a police officer arrests someone at 3 PM on Monday and takes them to court at 8 AM on Tuesday, how long can they legally hold the suspect before releasing them or charging them?
output: The police officer can legally hold the suspect for a maximum of 24 hours, which includes the time taken for the journey to the Magistrate's Court. Since the suspect was taken to court within 20 hours (from 3 PM Monday to 8 AM Tuesday), they have been held within the legal limit.
source_instruction: Explain Section 57 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973.

instruction: If someone accidentally bumps into me and I don't get injured, has the other person committed 'hurt' under Section 319 of the Indian Penal Code?
output: No, if you do not suffer from any bodily pain, disease, or infirmity as a result of being bumped into, then the other person has not caused 'hurt' as per Section 319 of the Indian Penal Code.
source_instruction: Explain Section 319 (Hurt) in simple terms.

instruction: If a High Court refers a question to itself for decision under Section 396, what action is required from the referring court?
output: The referring court shall dispose of the case conformably to the order passed by the High Court.
source_instruction: Summarize Section 396 of Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973.

instruction: What is the punishment for each person involved in committing dacoity where at least one person commits murder during the act?
output: every one of those persons shall be punished with death, or imprisonment for life, or rigorous imprisonment for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine
source_instruction: Summarize Section 396 of Indian Penal Code, 1860.

instruction: If three people plan a robbery and one of them later calls another to meet at the scene, can this call be used in court to prove the conspiracy?
output: Yes, if there is reasonable ground to believe that the three individuals had conspired to commit an offence, the call made by one of them to meet at the scene can be considered a relevant fact to prove the existence of the conspiracy and show that the individual who received the call was part of it.
source_instruction: Explain Section 10 (Things said or done by conspirator in reference to common design) in simple terms.

instruction: If John holds a cheque endorsed in blank and wants to direct the bank to pay the amount to Jane instead of the original endorse, what can he do according to Section 49?
output: John can write above the indorser's signature a direction to pay to Jane as indorsee without signing his own name, thus converting the indorsement in blank into an indorsement in full.
source_instruction: Explain Section 49 (Conversion of indorsement in blank into indorsement in full) in simple terms.

instruction: If a party has missed the deadline to file an appeal and 20 days have already passed since the original deadline, can the court still grant additional time under Section 148?
output: Yes, the court may, in its discretion, from time to time, enlarge such period even though the period originally fixed or granted may have expired, not exceeding thirty days in total.
source_instruction: Explain Section 148 of the Code of Civil Procedure, 1908.

instruction: If an army officer disperses an assembly under Section 131 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973, what should they do once communication with an Executive Magistrate is established?
output: he shall do so, and shall thenceforward obey the instructions of the Magistrate, as to whether he shall or shall not continue such action
source_instruction: What does Section 131 of Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973 state?

instruction: If someone accidentally throws a lit firecracker into a crowd during a festival, which punishment could they face under Section 336?
output: imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to three months or with fine which may extend to two hundred and fifty rupees, or with both
source_instruction: Explain Section 336 (Act endangering life or personal safety of others) in simple terms.

instruction: What action should the High Court take if a lower court convicts an accused who is found not unsound but unable to understand the proceedings?
output: the High Court shall pass thereon such order as it thinks fit
source_instruction: Summarize Section 318 of Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973.

instruction: If the state government issues a directive for certain cases to be tried in a specific sessions division, what happens if the high court has already directed these cases to be tried elsewhere?
output: Such direction by the state government is not allowed if it is repugnant to any direction previously issued by the High Court.
source_instruction: Summarize Section 185 of Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973.

instruction: If a conductor's license holder is disqualified for misconduct, how long can they be barred from holding or obtaining a conductor's license?
output: The holder of a conductor's licence can be disqualified for a specified period not exceeding one year.
source_instruction: Explain Section 34 (Power of licensing authority to disqualify) in simple terms.

instruction: If a person files a suit against another over land located in the local limits of two different courts due to uncertainty, what can happen according to Section 18?
output: Any one of those Courts may, if satisfied that there is ground for the alleged uncertainty, record a statement to that effect and thereupon proceed to entertain and dispose of any suit relating to that property, and its decree in the suit shall have the same effect as if the property were situate within the local limits of its jurisdiction.
source_instruction: Explain Section 18 (Place of institution of suit where local limits of jurisdiction of Courts are uncertain) in simple terms.

instruction: If a case is appealed to the High Court and the original decision was made by a Judicial Magistrate who is not the Chief Judicial Magistrate, how should the High Court's judgment be communicated back to the lower court?
output: The High Court's judgment or order shall be sent through the Chief Judicial Magistrate.
source_instruction: What does Section 388 of Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973 state?

instruction: If a person is ordered to appear in court but fails to do so, what action can the officer in charge of the prison take according to Section 270 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973?
output: The officer in charge of the prison shall cause the person named in the order to be taken to the Court in which his attendance is required, so as to be present there at the time mentioned in the order, and shall cause him to be kept in custody in or near the Court until he has been examined or until the Court authorises him to be taken back to the prison in which he was confined or detained.
source_instruction: What does Section 270 of Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973 state?

instruction: If two courts have decrees against the same property and the property is sold in execution of both decrees, which court will determine claims and objections to the attachment?
output: The Court of highest grade, or, where there is no difference in grade between such Courts, the Court under whose decree the property was first attached will determine any claim thereto and any objection to the attachment thereof.
source_instruction: Explain Section 63 of the Code of Civil Procedure, 1908.

instruction: If someone kidnaps another person and sells them into slavery, what punishment can they face under Section 367 of the Indian Penal Code, 1860?
output: imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to ten years
source_instruction: Summarize Section 367 of Indian Penal Code, 1860.

instruction: If a will is signed and attested by two witnesses but the testator later admits to signing it, can this admission alone prove the will's validity?
output: Yes, the admission of the testator to signing the will, which was executed by himself and attested by witnesses, is sufficient proof of its execution as against him.
source_instruction: Explain Section 70 of the Indian Evidence Act, 1872.

instruction: If a Chief Judicial Magistrate transfers a case to a subordinate Magistrate, can they later take back control of that case?
output: Yes, a Chief Judicial Magistrate may withdraw any case from, or recall any case which he has made over to, any Magistrate subordinate to him, and may inquire into or try such case himself.
source_instruction: Explain Section 410 (Withdrawal of cases by Judicial Magistrates) in simple terms.

instruction: Can a witness use a copy of a document to refresh their memory according to Section 159 of the Indian Evidence Act, 1872?
output: Yes, a witness may use a copy of a document to refresh their memory with the permission of the Court, provided the Court is satisfied that there is sufficient reason for the non-production of the original.
source_instruction: Explain Section 159 of the Indian Evidence Act, 1872.

instruction: If a case is taking too long to be disposed of by a Judicial Magistrate, what action can the High Court take according to Section 483 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973?
output: The High Court may exercise its superintendence over the Courts of Judicial Magistrates subordinate to it to ensure an expeditious and proper disposal of cases.
source_instruction: What does Section 483 of Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973 state?

instruction: If the Central Government issues a notification under Section 105L, what can they do regarding the application of Chapter 7 in a contracting state?
output: The Central Government can direct that the application of Chapter 7 in relation to a contracting state with which reciprocal arrangements have been made, shall be subject to such conditions, exceptions or qualifications as are specified in the said notification.
source_instruction: Explain Section 105L of the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973.

instruction: If someone threatens to accuse me of a crime that carries a sentence of more than 10 years in prison, what kind of punishment can they face under Section 388?
output: imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine
source_instruction: Explain Section 388 (Extortion by threat of accusation of an offence punishable with death or imprisonment for life, etc) in simple terms.

instruction: How do sections 151, 152 and 153 relate to policies of insurance according to the given text?
output: Sections 151, 152 and 153 refer to liabilities to third parties in relation to a person insured under any policy of insurance, but such reference does not include liability of that person as an insurer under another policy of insurance.
source_instruction: What does Section 154 of Motor Vehicles Act, 1988 state?

instruction: If a judge is unable to take down evidence in English due to a health issue, what should they do according to Section 138?
output: The judge shall record the reason and cause the evidence to be taken down in writing from his dictation in open Court.
source_instruction: Explain Section 138 (Power of High Court to require evidence to be recorded in English) in simple terms.

instruction: Which types of cases are excluded from the application of Sections 9, 91, 92, 94, 95, 96 to 112, and 115 of the Code of Civil Procedure, 1908?
output: Courts constituted under the Provincial Small Cause Courts Act, 1887 or the Berar Small Cause Courts Law, 1905, or Courts exercising the jurisdiction of a Court of Small Causes under these Acts or Laws, or Courts in any part of India to which the said Acts do not extend, exercising a corresponding jurisdiction.
source_instruction: What does Section 7 of Code of Civil Procedure, 1908 state?

instruction: If John takes a crossed cheque that says 'not negotiable' from Jane, can John sell this cheque to another person? Explain.
output: No, John cannot sell this cheque to another person as he does not have a better title to the cheque than what Jane had.
source_instruction: Summarize Section 130 of Negotiable Instruments Act, 1881.

instruction: If an accused is charged with criminal breach of trust, what specific details must the charge include according to Section 212 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973?
output: The charge shall contain such particulars as to the time and place of the alleged offence, and the person (if any) against whom, or the thing (if any) in respect of which, it was committed, as are reasonably sufficient to give the accused notice of the matter with which he is charged.
source_instruction: Summarize Section 212 of Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973.

instruction: If a person is not present in court and there's a fear of a breach of peace, what can the magistrate do?
output: The magistrate may issue a warrant for the immediate arrest of such person.
source_instruction: Explain Section 113 (Summons or warrant in case of person not so present) in simple terms.

instruction: If someone creates fake labels for a company's products without permission, what kind of punishment can they face according to Section 483 of the Indian Penal Code, 1860?
output: imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to two years, or with fine, or with both
source_instruction: Summarize Section 483 of Indian Penal Code, 1860.

instruction: If a person receives a notice of dishonor and wants to pass on this notice to an earlier party in the transaction, how much time does he have to do so according to Section 107?
output: A party receiving notice of dishonour transmits the notice within a reasonable time - if he transmits it within the same time after its receipt as he would have had to give notice if he had been the holder.
source_instruction: Explain Section 107 (Reasonable time for transmitting such notice) in simple terms.

instruction: If a person is summoned to produce a document but does not testify about its contents, can they be cross-examined?
output: No, a person summoned to produce a document does not become a witness by merely producing it and cannot be cross-examined unless and until he is called as a witness.
source_instruction: What does Section 139 of Indian Evidence Act, 1872 state?

instruction: If someone is caught breaking into a house at night and hiding inside without being noticed, what kind of punishment can they face according to Section 453?
output: imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to two years, and shall also be liable to fine
source_instruction: Explain Section 453 (Punishment for lurking house-trespass or house-breaking) in simple terms.

instruction: If a person mistakenly believes they have been ordered by a court to commit an action that is actually illegal, can they be held criminally responsible under Section 78 of the Indian Penal Code, 1860?
output: No, if the person did the act in good faith and believed that the court had the necessary jurisdiction, then the act is not considered an offense despite the mistake.
source_instruction: Explain Section 78 of the Indian Penal Code, 1860.

instruction: Can a court reverse a civil judgment because of an error in the joinder of parties if such error does not affect the merits of the case?
output: No, a court cannot reverse a civil judgment due to an error in the joinder of parties if such error does not impact the merits of the case.
source_instruction: Explain Section 99 of the Code of Civil Procedure, 1908.

instruction: If a High Court is trying a criminal case and not following section 407, what procedure should they follow according to Section 474 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973?
output: In the trial of the offence, the High Court shall observe the same procedure as a Court of Sessions would observe, if it were trying the case.
source_instruction: What does Section 474 of Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973 state?

instruction: If someone joins an unlawful assembly carrying a knife and participates in the assembly, what punishment can they face according to Section 144?
output: punishment with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to two years, or with fine, or with both
source_instruction: Explain Section 144 (Joining unlawful assembly armed with deadly weapon) in simple terms.

instruction: If a District Magistrate starts a criminal proceeding and later wants to take back control of the case, what can they do according to Section 411?
output: withdraw any case from, or recall any case which he has made over to, any Magistrate subordinate to him, and dispose of such proceeding himself
source_instruction: Explain Section 411 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973.

instruction: If a court declares property forfeited under Section 105H but cannot prove the source of only a portion of the property, what can the affected person do?
output: The affected person can choose to pay a fine instead of having the entire property forfeited. This fine will be equal to the market value of the unproven portion of the property.
source_instruction: Explain Section 105I of the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973.
