source_instruction: Explain Section 46 of the Code of Civil Procedure, 1908.

instruction: How do the proceedings under the Indian Divorce Act, 1869 for divorce cases between husband and wife get regulated?
output: all proceedings under this Act between party and party shall be regulated by the Code of Civil Procedure, 1908
source_instruction: What does Section 45 of Indian Divorce Act, 1869 state?

instruction: What does 'decree' mean according to Section 2 of the Code of Civil Procedure, 1908?
output: The term 'decree' refers to the formal expression of an adjudication which, so far as regards the Court expressing it, conclusively determines the rights of the parties with regard to all or any of the matters in controversy in the suit and may be either preliminary or final. It shall be deemed to include the rejection of a plaint and the determination of any question within section 144, but shall not include (a) any adjudication from which an appeal lies as an appeal from an order, or (b) any order of dismissal for default. A decree is preliminary when further proceedings have to be taken before the suit can be completely disposed of. It is final when such adjudication completely disposes of the suit. It may be partly preliminary and partly final.
source_instruction: Explain Section 2 (Definitions) in simple terms.

instruction: What does 'public officer' mean according to Section 2?
output: public officer means a person falling under any of the following descriptions, namely: (a) every Judge; (b) every member of an All-India Service; (c) every commissioned or gazetted officer in the military naval or air forces of the Union while serving under the Government; (d) Every officer of a court of Justice whose duty it is, as such officer, to investigate or report on any matter of law or fact, or to make, authenticate or keep any document, or to take charge or dispose of any property, or to execute any judicial process, or to administer any oath, or to interpret, or to preserve order, in the Court, and every person especially authorised by a court of Justice to perform any of such duties; (e) every person who holds any office by virtue of which he is empowered to place or keep any person in confinement; (f) every officer of the Government whose duty it is, as such officer, to prevent offences, to give information of offences, to bring offenders to justice, or to protect the public health, safety or convenience; (g) every officer whose duty it is, as such officer, to take, receive, keep or expend any property on behalf of the Government, or to make any survey, assessment or contract on behalf of the Government, or to execute any revenue process, or to investigate, or to report on, any matter affecting the pecuniary interests of the Government, or to make, authenticate or keep any document relating to the pecuniary interests of the Government, or to prevent the infraction of any law for the protection of the pecuniary interests of the Government; and (h) every officer in the service or pay of the Government, or remunerated by fees or commission for the performance of any public duty;
source_instruction: Explain Section 2 (Definitions) in simple terms.

instruction: If a person plans to counterfeit coins in another country but does not actually do so, what punishment can they face under Section 236 of the Indian Penal Code, 1860?
output: He shall be punished in the same manner as if he abetted the counterfeiting of such coin within India.
source_instruction: Summarize Section 236 of Indian Penal Code, 1860.

instruction: If someone is restrained from leaving their home by their spouse and remains inside for 2 hours, what kind of punishment can they face under Section 341 of the Indian Penal Code, 1860?
output: simple imprisonment for a term which may extend to one month, or with fine which may extend to five hundred rupees, or with both
source_instruction: What does Section 341 of Indian Penal Code, 1860 state?

instruction: If someone uses an old government stamp knowing it was previously used, what punishment can they face according to Section 262?
output: imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to two years, or with fine, or with both
source_instruction: Explain Section 262 (Using Government stamp known to have been before used) in simple terms.

instruction: If a Sessions Judge calls for a record from an inferior court under Section 397, what can they do?
output: The Sessions Judge can call for and examine the record of any proceeding before an inferior criminal court to satisfy themselves regarding the correctness, legality, or propriety of findings, sentences, orders, or proceedings. They can also direct the suspension of the execution of any sentence or order and release the accused on bail or their own bond if in confinement.
source_instruction: Explain Section 397 (Calling for records to exercise powers of revision) in simple terms.

instruction: If a husband files for divorce because his wife has been suffering from a mental disorder for over five years, can he get a divorce under Section 13(1)(iii)?
output: Yes, if the mental disorder of the wife is such that the husband cannot reasonably be expected to live with her.
source_instruction: Explain Section 13 (Divorce.) in simple terms.

instruction: If a wife presents a petition for divorce based on the husband's persistent cruelty, what additional condition must be met?
output: there must be a reasonable apprehension in the mind of the petitioner that it will be harmful or injurious for the petitioner to live with the other party
source_instruction: Explain Section 13 (Divorce.) in simple terms.

instruction: If an individual is found guilty of abetting the commission of theft (which carries a maximum sentence of 7 years) and the theft itself also results in damage to property (which carries a maximum sentence of 3 years), how should the punishment be determined according to Section 112?
output: The abettor is liable to punishment for each of the offences. Therefore, the abettor is liable to punishment for both the act of abetting theft (maximum 7 years) and the act of damaging property (maximum 3 years).
source_instruction: Explain Section 112 of the Indian Penal Code, 1860.

instruction: If a court issues a decree for the payment of money and the debtor is a woman, can she be arrested and put in jail to enforce the decree?
output: No, the Court shall not order the arrest or detention in the civil prison of a woman in execution of a decree for the payment of money.
source_instruction: Explain Section 56 (Prohibition of arrest or detention of women in execution of decree for money) in simple terms.

instruction: In what situations can a holder of a cheque avoid giving notice of dishonor under Section 98 of the Negotiable Instruments Act, 1881?
output: when it is dispensed with by the party entitled thereto; in order to charge the drawer when he has countermanded payment; when the party charged could not suffer damage for want of notice; when the party entitled to notice cannot after due search be found; or the party bound to give notice is, for any other reason, unable without any fault of his own to give it;
source_instruction: What does Section 98 of Negotiable Instruments Act, 1881 state?

instruction: If a judge wants to issue an order to stop someone from filing frivolous lawsuits, can they do so under Section 482?
output: Yes, a judge can issue such an order under the inherent powers of the High Court as stated in Section 482 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973.
source_instruction: Explain Section 482 (Saving of inherent power of High Court) in simple terms.

instruction: If a boat owner hires out a boat that is known to be unsafe and overloaded, what punishment can they face under Section 282?
output: imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to six months, or with fine which may extend to one thousand rupees, or with both
source_instruction: Explain Section 282 (Conveying person by water for hire in unsafe or overloaded vessel) in simple terms.

instruction: If someone throws acid on another person's face with the intent to cause disfigurement, what punishment can they receive under Section 326A?
output: imprisonment of either description for a term which shall not be less than ten years but which may extend to imprisonment for life, and with fine
source_instruction: Explain Section 326A (Voluntarily causing grievous hurt by use of acid, etc.) in simple terms.

instruction: If a witness is questioned about their past criminal record during cross-examination, can opposing counsel introduce evidence of the witness's good character to contradict their answer?
output: No, when a witness has been asked and has answered any question which is relevant to the inquiry only in so far as it tends to shake his credit by injuring his character, no evidence shall be given to contradict him.
source_instruction: Explain Section 153 of the Indian Evidence Act, 1872.

instruction: If a court finds it necessary to adjourn a trial involving offenses under Sections 376 of the Indian Penal Code, how long can the adjournment last?
output: The inquiry or trial shall be completed within a period of two months from the date of filing of the charge sheet. However, the Court may, from time to time, adjourn the same for reasons to be recorded, for such time as it considers reasonable.
source_instruction: Explain Section 309 (Power to postpone or adjourn proceedings) in simple terms.

instruction: If the Central Government wants to appoint an additional Public Prosecutor, what is required according to Section 24 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973?
output: The Central Government may appoint one or more Additional Public Prosecutor without any specific requirement of consultation.
source_instruction: Summarize Section 24 of Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973.

instruction: If a police officer, who is a public servant, intentionally records a crime incorrectly in his report to cause loss to the victim, what could be the possible intention behind his action according to Section 218 of the Indian Penal Code, 1860?
output: with intent to cause, or knowing it to be likely that he will thereby cause, loss or injury to the public or to any person
source_instruction: Summarize Section 218 of Indian Penal Code, 1860.

instruction: If someone impersonates a police officer and tries to arrest a person without any authority, what punishment can they face according to Section 170?
output: imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to two years, or with fine, or with both
source_instruction: Explain Section 170 (Personating a public servant) in simple terms.

instruction: If a complaint is made against an individual named John Doe who resides at 123 Main Street, what details should be recorded by the Metropolitan Magistrate according to Section 355 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973?
output: the serial number of the case; the date of the commission of the offence; the name of the complainant (if any); the name of the accused person, John Doe, and his parentage and residence, 123 Main Street; the offence complained of or proved; the plea of the accused and
source_instruction: Summarize Section 355 of Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973.

instruction: What can the State Government do under Section 215D of the Motor Vehicles Act, 1988?
output: The State Government can make rules for the purposes of carrying into effect the provisions of this Chapter, other than the matters specified in section 215C. Such rules may provide for the use of electronic forms and means for the filing of documents, issue or grant of.
source_instruction: Summarize Section 215D of Motor Vehicles Act, 1988.

instruction: If a person consumes alcohol unknowingly and commits an offense due to its effects, can they be held criminally responsible under Section 85 of the Indian Penal Code, 1860?
output: No, if the person consumed something that intoxicated them without their knowledge or against their will, then according to Section 85 of the Indian Penal Code, 1860, they cannot be held criminally responsible for any act done while under the influence of such substance.
source_instruction: Explain Section 85 of the Indian Penal Code, 1860.

instruction: If a vehicle was registered under the old act in 1939 and the new act came into effect in 2023, what happens to the registration?
output: Any certificate of fitness or registration or licence or permit issued under the repealed enactments shall continue to have effect after such commencement under the same conditions and for the same period as if this Act had not been passed.
source_instruction: Explain Section 217 (Repeal and savings) in simple terms.

instruction: If a suspect is arrested and the police believe another witness needs to identify him, what action can the court take according to Section 54A of the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973?
output: The Court, having jurisdiction, may on the request of the officer in charge of a police station, direct the person so arrested to subject himself to identification by any person or persons in such manner as
source_instruction: Summarize Section 54A of Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973.

instruction: A person files a complaint against another for an offense which falls under the jurisdiction of a different court. What should the magistrate do if the complaint is in writing?
output: return it for presentation to the proper Court with an endorsement to that effect
source_instruction: What does Section 201 of Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973 state?

instruction: If someone has a learner's license from Delhi, can they drive a vehicle in Mumbai?
output: Yes, a learner's license issued under the Motor Vehicles Act, 1988 is effective throughout India.
source_instruction: Explain Section 13 (Extent of effectiveness of licences, to drive motor vehicles) in simple terms.

instruction: If someone is caught selling slaves multiple times over several years, what kind of punishment can they face according to Section 371?
output: imprisonment for life, or with imprisonment of either description for a term not exceeding ten years, and shall also be liable to fine
source_instruction: Summarize Section 371 of Indian Penal Code, 1860.

instruction: If a person is found guilty of misappropriating property belonging to a deceased individual who had no known heirs or legal representatives, what punishment can they face according to Section 404 of the Indian Penal Code, 1860?
output: imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to three years, and shall also be liable to fine
source_instruction: Explain Section 404 of the Indian Penal Code, 1860.

instruction: Can a theft (which is an offence under the Indian Penal Code) be compounded?
output: Yes, if the theft is punishable under the sections of the Indian Penal Code specified in the first two columns of the Table and the compounding is done by the persons mentioned in the third column of that Table.
source_instruction: Explain Section 320 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973.

instruction: If someone commits theft and later returns the stolen property without getting caught, can they be charged under Section 320 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973?
output: No, because theft is listed as a compoundable offense under IPC Section 379, and the section does not mention any provision for returning stolen property.
source_instruction: Explain Section 320 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973.

instruction: Can a minor's guardian compound an offense under Section 320 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973?
output: Yes, when the person who would otherwise be competent to compound an offence under this section is under the age of eighteen years, any person competent to contract on his behalf, may, with the permission of the Court compound such offence.
source_instruction: Explain Section 320 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973.

instruction: Can a court allow a composition for an offense where the accused has already been convicted and an appeal is pending?
output: Yes, a High Court or Court of Session acting in the exercise of its powers of revision under section 401 may allow any person to compound any offence which such person is competent to compound under this section.
source_instruction: Explain Section 320 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973.

instruction: If a person is convicted of rape (Section 376) after being previously convicted of sexual assault (Section 376A), what kind of punishment will they face according to Section 376E?
output: imprisonment for life which shall mean imprisonment for the remainder of that person's natural life, or with death
source_instruction: What does Section 376E of Indian Penal Code, 1860 state?

instruction: If a party missed the original deadline set by the court but the court has already closed for the day, can the court still grant an extension under Section 148?
output: Yes, the court may, in its discretion, from time to time, enlarge such period even though the period originally fixed or granted may have expired, up to a maximum of thirty days in total.
source_instruction: Summarize Section 148 of Code of Civil Procedure, 1908.

instruction: Can evidence be given to clarify the meaning of modern English words according to Section 98 of the Indian Evidence Act, 1872?
output: No, Section 98 of the Indian Evidence Act, 1872 allows evidence to be given to show the meaning of illegible or not commonly intelligible characters, of foreign, obsolete, technical, local and provincial expressions, of abbreviations and of words used in a peculiar sense.
source_instruction: What does Section 98 of Indian Evidence Act, 1872 state?

instruction: What happens if a person is released after an inquiry under Section 116 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973?
output: if such person is in custody only for the purposes of the inquiry, shall release him, or, if such person is not in custody, shall discharge him.
source_instruction: What does Section 118 of Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973 state?

instruction: If someone is caught belonging to a group of people who regularly commit dacoities, what kind of punishment can they face according to Section 400?
output: imprisonment for life, or with rigorous imprisonment for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine
source_instruction: Explain Section 400 (Punishment for belonging to gang of dacoits) in simple terms.

instruction: If an accused person provides information to a police officer during interrogation and later denies it in court, can the information given by the accused be used against them according to Section 27 of the Indian Evidence Act, 1872?
output: Yes, if the information received from the accused is relevant and admissible as evidence, it may be proved against the accused in accordance with Section 27 of the Indian Evidence Act, 1872.
source_instruction: Under which Act does Section 27 titled 'How much of information received from accused may be proved' fall?

instruction: If a person is sentenced to life imprisonment but is currently at home, what should happen according to Section 418?
output: The Court passing the sentence shall forthwith forward a warrant to the jail and the accused shall be forwarded to such jail with the warrant.
source_instruction: Explain Section 418 (Execution of sentence of imprisonment) in simple terms.

instruction: If a person is found guilty of committing undue influence and personation at an election, what kind of punishment can they face?
output: imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to one year or with fine, or with both
source_instruction: Summarize Section 171F of Indian Penal Code, 1860.

instruction: If a person incites a soldier to disobey orders and the soldier commits an act of insubordination as a result, what kind of punishment can the inciter face according to Section 138 of the Indian Penal Code, 1860?
output: imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to six months, or with fine, or with both
source_instruction: Summarize Section 138 of Indian Penal Code, 1860.

instruction: If the state government decides to restrict the use of trucks on a particular highway due to recent accidents, what actions can they take according to Section 115?
output: The State Government can issue a notification in the Official Gazette prohibiting or restricting the use of trucks on the specified highway. They can specify exceptions and conditions and place appropriate traffic signs under section 116 at suitable places.
source_instruction: Explain Section 115 (Power to restrict the use of vehicles) in simple terms.

instruction: Can a 17-year-old obtain a learner's license to drive a motor cycle without gear?
output: No, a person under the age of eighteen years cannot be granted a learners license to drive a motor cycle without gear without the consent in writing of the person having the care of the person desiring the learners license.
source_instruction: Explain Section 7 of the Motor Vehicles Act, 1988.

instruction: If a statute mentions 'person', does it also include corporations under Indian Penal Code, 1860?
output: Yes, unless the contrary appears from the context, words importing the singular number (like 'person') include the plural number (such as 'corporations').
source_instruction: Explain Section 9 of the Indian Penal Code, 1860.

instruction: If a person fraudulently hides money owed to them and their friend, preventing it from being used to pay off their mutual debts, what punishment can they face under Section 422 of the Indian Penal Code, 1860?
output: imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to two years, or with fine, or with both
source_instruction: What does Section 422 of Indian Penal Code, 1860 state?

instruction: If a document refers to 'a Magistrate' without specifying a class, how should it be interpreted in a non-metropolitan area?
output: in relation to an area outside a metropolitan area, as a reference to a Judicial Magistrate
source_instruction: Explain Section 3 (Construction of references) in simple terms.

instruction: If a registered medical practitioner conducts a rape examination without obtaining consent from the victim or a person authorized to give consent, what can be inferred according to the statute?
output: The statute implies that conducting a rape examination without the consent of the woman or a person competent to give such consent would be unlawful.
source_instruction: What does Section 164A of Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973 state?

instruction: If a proposal for a new bus route is made and someone objects to it, what happens next according to Section 100?
output: The State Government may, after considering the objections and after giving an opportunity to the objector or their representatives and the representatives of the State transport undertaking to be heard in the matter, if they so desire, approve or modify such proposal.
source_instruction: Explain Section 100 (Objection to the proposal) in simple terms.

instruction: If a soldier is assaulted by another soldier under the influence of an instigator who is not a superior officer, will the instigator be punished under Section 134 of the Indian Penal Code, 1860?
output: No, the instigator will not be punished under Section 134 of the Indian Penal Code, 1860 as the assault was not committed by an officer, soldier, sailor or airman on any superior officer in the execution of their office.
source_instruction: Summarize Section 134 of Indian Penal Code, 1860.

instruction: If an issue of fact was wrongly decided by the lower appellate court due to a misinterpretation of a point of law, can the High Court determine that issue under Section 103?
output: Yes, the High Court may determine the issue of fact if it was wrongly determined by the lower appellate court due to a misinterpretation of a point of law, as per subsection (b) of Section 103.
source_instruction: Explain Section 103 of the Code of Civil Procedure, 1908.

instruction: If a state government wants to improve road safety, what can they do according to Section 67?
output: A State Government may issue directions regarding road safety from time to time by notification in the Official Gazette to the State Transport Authority and Regional Transport Authority.
source_instruction: Explain Section 67 (Power to State Government to control road transport) in simple terms.

instruction: If a husband files a petition under Section 9 claiming restitution of conjugal rights, what must the court consider before granting the petition?
output: The court must be satisfied of the truth of the statements made in the petition and that there is no legal ground why the application should not be granted.
source_instruction: Explain Section 9 (Restitution of conjugal right.) in simple terms.

instruction: If a police officer is patrolling a neighborhood and a resident verbally threatens to call the police if they continue their patrol, has the resident committed an offense under Section 353 of the Indian Penal Code, 1860?
output: No, the resident has not committed an offense under Section 353 of the Indian Penal Code, 1860 because there was no physical assault or use of criminal force against the police officer.
source_instruction: Explain Section 353 of the Indian Penal Code, 1860.

instruction: If someone is planning to commit dacoity but is caught before they can execute their plan, what kind of punishment can they face according to Section 399 of the Indian Penal Code, 1860?
output: rigorous imprisonment for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine
source_instruction: What does Section 399 of Indian Penal Code, 1860 state?

instruction: If Police Officer A is investigating a crime and needs to conduct a search at a location under Police Station B's jurisdiction, what action can Officer A take according to Section 166 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973?
output: Police Officer A can require the officer in charge of Police Station B to cause a search to be made in the specified location.
source_instruction: Summarize Section 166 of Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973.

instruction: If a Regional Transport Authority grants a contract carriage permit for a vehicle to operate within a specific area, what conditions can they impose?
output: The Regional Transport Authority can impose conditions such as the use of the vehicle only in a specified area or on a specified route, restrictions on entering into contracts outside the specified area, limits on the number of passengers and weight of luggage, conditions for carrying goods, charging specified fares or rates of fares, maintaining a taximeter, ensuring specified standards of comfort and cleanliness, and not refusing plying or carrying passengers except in exceptional circumstances.
source_instruction: Explain Section 74 of the Motor Vehicles Act, 1988.

instruction: If a town with a population of 500,000 people wants to limit the number of contract carriages operating on its city routes, what should they do according to Section 74?
output: The State Government should, if so directed by the Central Government, having regard to the number of vehicles, road conditions and other relevant matters, by notification in the Official Gazette, direct a State Transport Authority and a Regional Transport Authority to limit the number of contract carriages generally or of any specified type, as may be fixed and specified in the notification, operating on city routes in towns with a population of not less than five lakhs.
source_instruction: Explain Section 74 of the Motor Vehicles Act, 1988.

instruction: What happens if the holder of a bill of exchange gives the drawee more than 48 hours to decide on acceptance?
output: All previous parties not consenting to such allowance are thereby discharged from liability to such holder.
source_instruction: Explain Section 83 of the Negotiable Instruments Act, 1881.

instruction: What actions can a Magistrate take if they are not authorized by law?
output: A Magistrate cannot issue a search-warrant under section 94, order the police to investigate an offence under section 155, hold an inquest under section 176, or issue process under section 187 for the apprehension of a person who has committed an offence outside their local jurisdiction.
source_instruction: Summarize Section 460 of Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973.

instruction: If a state government wants to impose certain conditions on the sale of land in a specific region, how can they do it according to Section 67?
output: The state government can make rules for any local area imposing conditions in respect of the sale of any class of interests in land in execution of decrees for the payment of money, where such interests are so uncertain or undetermined as, in the opinion of the state government, to make it impossible to fix their value.
source_instruction: Explain Section 67 (Power for State Government to make rules as to sales of land in execution of decrees for payment of money) in simple terms.

instruction: If three individuals plan to rob a bank and one of them provides the getaway car but they do not actually carry out the robbery, what punishment can be imposed under Section 120B of the Indian Penal Code, 1860?
output: Where no express provision is made in this Code for the punishment of such a conspiracy, the party who provided the getaway car would be punished in the same manner as if he had abetted the robbery.
source_instruction: What does Section 120B of Indian Penal Code, 1860 state?

instruction: If an individual is entrusted with someone's property to sell it on their behalf but instead keeps the money for themselves, what punishment can they face under Section 409 of the Indian Penal Code, 1860?
output: imprisonment for life, or with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.
source_instruction: What does Section 409 of Indian Penal Code, 1860 state?

instruction: If someone tries to take an overdose but changes their mind before taking it, what kind of punishment can they face under Section 309 of the Indian Penal Code, 1860?
output: simple imprisonment for a term which may extend to one year or with fine, or with both
source_instruction: What does Section 309 of Indian Penal Code, 1860 state?

instruction: If a witness provides non-essential testimony during an inquiry, can the court summon them again for further examination?
output: No, the court will not summon and examine any such person if their initial evidence does not appear to be essential to the just decision of the case.
source_instruction: What does Section 311 of Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973 state?

instruction: If a person is asked by a police officer (a public servant) to provide truthful information regarding an ongoing investigation and refuses to do so, what punishment can they face under Section 179 of the Indian Penal Code, 1860?
output: with simple imprisonment for a term which may extend to six months, or with fine which may extend to one thousand rupees, or with both
source_instruction: Summarize Section 179 of Indian Penal Code, 1860.

instruction: If a ship's captain is aware that there is an infectious disease on board but does not follow the government's quarantine rules, what punishment can they face under Section 271?
output: imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to six months, or with fine, or with both
source_instruction: Explain Section 271 of the Indian Penal Code, 1860.

instruction: If a person owns a hotel and rents out rooms to individuals who later participate in an unlawful assembly, can they be charged under Section 157 of the Indian Penal Code, 1860?
output: Yes, if the owner of the hotel knows that the renters were hired, engaged or employed to join or become members of an unlawful assembly, then the owner could be punished under Section 157 of the Indian Penal Code, 1860.
source_instruction: Explain Section 157 of the Indian Penal Code, 1860.

instruction: If a witness holds property as a pledgee and is not a party to the suit, under what condition can their title-deed be produced?
output: unless he has agreed in writing to produce them with the person seeking the production of such deeds
source_instruction: Explain Section 130 (Production of title-deeds of witness not a party) in simple terms.

instruction: If a driver is found driving a motor vehicle with a left-hand steering control without a functioning signaling device, what can be inferred from the statute?
output: The driver has violated the provisions of Section 120 of the Motor Vehicles Act, 1988 as the vehicle was not equipped with a mechanical or electrical signalling device of a prescribed nature and in working order.
source_instruction: Summarize Section 120 of Motor Vehicles Act, 1988.

instruction: If a driver is convicted of a traffic offense and given a disqualification order, what should happen according to the statute?
output: The Court or authority making the order of disqualification shall endorse or cause to be endorsed upon the driving licence held by the person disqualified, particulars of the order of disqualification and of any conviction of an offence in respect of which an order of disqualification is made.
source_instruction: Explain Section 24 (Endorsement) in simple terms.

instruction: If a police officer intentionally records a crime scene incorrectly to prevent a suspect from facing charges, what kind of punishment can they face under Section 218 of the Indian Penal Code, 1860?
output: imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to three years, or with fine, or with both
source_instruction: What does Section 218 of Indian Penal Code, 1860 state?

instruction: If a cheque bounces, how can the bank notify the drawer according to Section 94?
output: The bank can notify the drawer of the bounced cheque either orally or in writing. If written, it can be sent by post. It must clearly state that the cheque was dishonoured and why, and inform the drawer that they will be held liable. This notification must be given within a reasonable time at the drawer's place of business or residence.
source_instruction: Explain Section 94 (Mode in which notice may be given) in simple terms.

instruction: What can the Central Government do under Section 88A of the Motor Vehicles Act, 1988?
output: The Central Government can modify any permit issued under the Motor Vehicles Act, 1988 or make schemes for national, multimodal and inter-State transportation of goods or passengers.
source_instruction: Summarize Section 88A of Motor Vehicles Act, 1988.

instruction: If someone wants to operate a bus service between two cities, what details should they provide in their application for a contract carriage permit according to Section 73?
output: The application for a contract carriage permit should contain the following particulars: (a) the type and seating capacity of the vehicle; (b) the area for which the permit is required; (c) any other particulars which may be prescribed.
source_instruction: Explain Section 73 (Application for contract carriage permit) in simple terms.

instruction: If someone threatens to damage another's property unless they hand over their phone, has the condition for 'extortion' under Section 383 been met?
output: Yes, if the person threatened to cause injury to the other's property and induced them to deliver their phone, which can be converted into a valuable security, then the conditions for 'extortion' under Section 383 have been met.
source_instruction: Explain Section 383 of the Indian Penal Code, 1860.

instruction: If someone breaks into a house and prepares to hit the homeowner but does not actually do so, what punishment can they face under Section 452?
output: imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to seven years, and shall also be liable to fine
source_instruction: Summarize Section 452 of Indian Penal Code, 1860.

instruction: If a surety for a bond becomes insolvent, what action can the court take according to Section 447?
output: The court may order the person from whom such security was demanded to furnish fresh security in accordance with the directions of the original order.
source_instruction: Explain Section 447 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973.

instruction: If someone helps their friend hide a stolen bicycle they know about, what kind of punishment can they face under Section 414?
output: imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to three years, or with fine, or with both
source_instruction: What does Section 414 of Indian Penal Code, 1860 state?

instruction: If a wife has left her husband's home without any valid reason, can he file a petition under Section 32 of the Indian Divorce Act, 1869?
output: Yes, if the husband can prove that his wife has withdrawn from their society without reasonable excuse, he can file a petition for restitution of conjugal rights.
source_instruction: Explain Section 32 of the Indian Divorce Act, 1869.

instruction: How does Section 100 of the Indian Evidence Act, 1872 interact with the Indian Succession Act regarding wills?
output: Section 100 of the Indian Evidence Act, 1872 does not affect the provisions of the Indian Succession Act as to the construction of wills.
source_instruction: What does Section 100 of Indian Evidence Act, 1872 state?

instruction: If a person is suspected of committing a non-cognizable offense and refuses to provide their name and address when asked by a police officer, what action can the officer take according to Section 42 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973?
output: The police officer may arrest the person in order to ascertain their true name and residence.
source_instruction: Summarize Section 42 of Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973.

instruction: If an investigating officer wants to obtain evidence from abroad, what steps can they take according to Section 166A of the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973?
output: An investigating officer can make an application for evidence from a foreign country. If the application is approved by an officer superior in rank, a Criminal Court may issue a letter of request to a competent authority in that country to examine a person acquainted with the facts and circumstances of the case, record their statement, and produce relevant documents or things. The evidence obtained will be considered as collected during the course of investigation.
source_instruction: What does Section 166A of Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973 state?

instruction: If a police officer tries to take away an item from someone and the person believes the officer has the right to do so but still resists, what punishment can they face according to Section 183?
output: with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to six months, or with fine which may extend to one thousand rupees, or with both
source_instruction: Explain Section 183 (Resistance to the taking of property by the lawful authority of a public servant) in simple terms.

instruction: If someone enters a graveyard out of curiosity and does not intend to wound anyone's feelings or insult any religion, but accidentally leaves graffiti on a tombstone, can they be charged under Section 297 of the Indian Penal Code, 1860?
output: No, because the section requires the act to be done with the intention of wounding the feelings of any person, or of insulting the religion of any person, or with the knowledge that the feelings of any person are likely to be wounded, or that the religion of any person is likely to be insulted thereby.
source_instruction: Explain Section 297 of the Indian Penal Code, 1860.

instruction: If someone breaks into my house and tries to steal something, can I use reasonable force to stop them?
output: Yes, you have a right to defend your property against an act that falls under the definition of theft, as long as the force used is reasonable.
source_instruction: Explain Section 97 of the Indian Penal Code, 1860.

instruction: If a person commits an act while under the influence of alcohol but seems to understand the nature of the act and knows it's wrong, how should the Magistrate handle the case according to Section 333 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973?
output: The Magistrate shall proceed with the case as the accused appears to be of sound mind at the time of inquiry or trial and there is no reason to believe that the accused was, at the time when the act was committed, by reason of unsoundness of mind, incapable of knowing the nature of the act or that it was wrong or contrary to law.
source_instruction: Explain Section 333 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973.

instruction: If someone files a false police report against you without evidence, what kind of punishment can they face under Section 211 of the Indian Penal Code, 1860?
output: punishment with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to two years, or with fine, or with both
source_instruction: What does Section 211 of Indian Penal Code, 1860 state?

instruction: If an offense does not specify a maximum fine, what can be said about the possible fine according to Section 63?
output: The amount of fine to which the offender is liable is unlimited, but shall not be excessive.
source_instruction: Explain Section 63 (Amount of fine) in simple terms.

instruction: If a company's financial records are missing due to a fire, under which clause can the company provide secondary evidence of the financial status?
output: when the original has been destroyed or lost, or when the party offering evidence of its contents cannot, for any other reason not arising from his own default or neglect, produce it in reasonable time;
source_instruction: Explain Section 65 (Cases in which secondary evidence relating to documents may be given) in simple terms.

instruction: If a witness objects to their recorded statement during the reading back process, what can the magistrate do according to Section 278?
output: The magistrate may make a memorandum of the objection made by the witness and add such remarks as he thinks necessary.
source_instruction: Explain Section 278 (Procedure in regard to such evidence when completed) in simple terms.

instruction: What happens if the High Court of Judicature at Fort William decides to extend certain provisions of the Code of Civil Procedure to the Small Causes Court in Calcutta?
output: The High Court of Judicature at Fort William can, from time to time, by notification in the Official Gazette, direct that any such provisions not inconsistent with the express provisions of the Presidency Small Cause Courts Act, 1882, and with such modifications and adaptations as may be specified in the notification, shall extend to suits or proceedings or any class of suits or proceedings in such Court.
source_instruction: Explain Section 8 (Presidency Small Cause Courts) in simple terms.

instruction: If a court in a state without the Code of Criminal Procedure sentences someone to pay a fine, can they issue a warrant to a collector in another state where the Code applies?
output: Yes, if a criminal court in a territory to which the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973 does not extend sentences an offender to pay a fine and issues a warrant to the Collector of a district in the territories to which the Code extends, then such warrant will be considered as a warrant issued under the Code and its provisions for execution will apply accordingly.
source_instruction: Explain Section 423 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973.

instruction: If a person owns a motor vehicle and wants to drive it temporarily within their state for a week, what should they do according to Section 43 of the Motor Vehicles Act, 1988?
output: The owner of a motor vehicle may apply to any registering authority or other authority as may be prescribed by the State Government to have the motor vehicle temporarily registered and such authority shall issue a temporary certificate of registration and temporary registration mark in accordance with such rules as may be made by the Central Government.
source_instruction: Explain Section 43 of the Motor Vehicles Act, 1988.

instruction: If someone intentionally hurts a police officer while he is on duty, what punishment can they face according to Section 332?
output: They can be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to three years, or with fine, or with both.
source_instruction: Explain Section 332 (Voluntarily causing hurt to deter public servant from his duty) in simple terms.

instruction: If a person enters into a second marriage without disclosing their previous marriage, what punishment can they face under Section 495 of the Indian Penal Code, 1860?
output: imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine
source_instruction: Summarize Section 495 of Indian Penal Code, 1860.

instruction: If a High Court confirms a sentence of death and sends an order to the Court of Session, what action is required according to Section 413 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973?
output: The Court of Session shall cause such order to be carried into effect by issuing a warrant or taking such other steps as may be necessary.
source_instruction: What does Section 413 of Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973 state?

instruction: If a person purchases a motor vehicle from an authorized dealer, is the vehicle required to be produced before a registering authority for the first registration?
output: No, subject to such terms and conditions as may be prescribed by the Central Government in this behalf, a motor vehicle sold by an authorised dealer shall not require production before a registering authority for the purposes of registration for the first time.
source_instruction: Summarize Section 44 of Motor Vehicles Act, 1988.

instruction: If a witness testifies that a suspect was seen near the crime scene on the night of the incident, what type of evidence would this be considered under Section 9 of the Indian Evidence Act, 1872?
output: This would be considered a fact necessary to introduce the relevant fact of the suspect's presence near the crime scene, and thus is relevant insofar as it is necessary for that purpose.
source_instruction: Explain Section 9 of the Indian Evidence Act, 1872.

instruction: If someone possesses a forged birth certificate and intends to use it to falsely claim their age for a job, what punishment can they face under Section 474 of the Indian Penal Code, 1860?
output: imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to seven years
source_instruction: Summarize Section 474 of Indian Penal Code, 1860.

instruction: If a negotiable instrument is dishonored, what details must be included in the protest according to Section 101 of the Negotiable Instruments Act, 1881?
output: When a note or bill has been dishonoured, the place and time of dishonour must be stated in the protest.
source_instruction: What does Section 101 of Negotiable Instruments Act, 1881 state?

instruction: If the Attorney-General of India applies to the Supreme Court to transfer a criminal case from one High Court to another, what must accompany the application?
output: the application shall be made by motion, which shall be supported by affidavit or affirmation
source_instruction: Explain Section 406 (Power of Supreme Court to transfer cases and appeals) in simple terms.

instruction: If an applicant wants to apply for a goods carriage permit under the Motor Vehicles Act, 1988, what details must they provide in their application?
output: The application for a goods carriage permit must contain the following particulars: (a) the area or the route or routes to which the application relates; (b) the type and capacity of the vehicle; (c) the nature of the goods it is proposed to carry; (d) the arrangements intended to be made for the housing, maintenance and repair of the vehicle and for the storage and safe custody of the goods; (e) such particulars as the Regional Transport Authority may require with respect to any business as a carrier of goods for hire or reward carried on by the applicant at any time before the making of the application, and of the rates charged by the applicant; (f) particulars of any agreement, or arrangement, affecting in any material respect the provision within the region of the Regional Transport Authority of facilities for the transport of goods for hire or reward, entered into by the applicant with any other person by whom such facilities are provided, whether within or without the region; (g) any other particulars which may be prescribed.
source_instruction: What does Section 77 of Motor Vehicles Act, 1988 state?

instruction: If a person is accused of two distinct offenses, how should they be charged and tried according to Section 218 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973?
output: For every distinct offence of which any person is accused there shall be a separate charge and every such charge shall be tried separately;
source_instruction: Explain Section 218 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973.

instruction: If someone attacks you and you cause their death in self-defense, under what conditions can this be justified according to Section 100 of the Indian Penal Code, 1860?
output: the offence which occasions the exercise of the right be of any of the descriptions hereinafter enumerated
source_instruction: Summarize Section 100 of Indian Penal Code, 1860.

instruction: If someone intentionally stops a property auction being conducted by a government official, what punishment can they face according to Section 184?
output: imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to one month, or with fine which may extend to five hundred rupees, or with both
source_instruction: Explain Section 184 (Obstructing sale of property offered for sale by authority of public servant) in simple terms.

instruction: If a person demands a certified copy of a public document from an officer who has the custody of it, what should the officer provide?
output: The officer should provide a copy of the document on payment of the legal fees, along with a certificate stating that it is a true copy of the document or part thereof, as the case may be. The certificate should be dated, signed by the officer with their name and official title, and sealed if authorized by law.
source_instruction: Explain Section 76 (Certified copies of public documents) in simple terms.

instruction: If an appellate court finds that the original judge did not properly consider certain evidence, what can they do?
output: The Appellate Court may reverse the order of acquittal and direct that further inquiry be made, or that the accused be re-tried or committed for trial.
source_instruction: Explain Section 386 (Powers of the Appellate Court) in simple terms.

instruction: If a person commits an offense punishable by imprisonment for two years and another offense punishable by a fine, what is the period of limitation within which the court can take cognizance of these offenses?
output: The period of limitation for both offenses combined will be determined based on the more severe punishment, which in this case is imprisonment for two years. Therefore, the period of limitation is three years.
source_instruction: Explain Section 468 (Bar to taking cognizance after lapse of the period of limitation) in simple terms.

instruction: Can a person use private defense to cause injury to a thief who is stealing property without causing death?
output: Yes, a person can use private defense to cause injury to a thief who is stealing property without causing death, as long as the injury caused is not excessive and the right of private defense extends to causing harm other than death for offenses like theft.
source_instruction: Explain Section 104 of the Indian Penal Code, 1860.

instruction: If a person is lawfully summoned to produce a document but instead destroys it, what punishment can they face under Section 204 of the Indian Penal Code, 1860?
output: imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to two years, or with fine, or with both
source_instruction: Explain Section 204 of the Indian Penal Code, 1860.

instruction: Can the Regional Transport Authority deny an application for a motor vehicle permit if it is submitted after business hours?
output: No, the Regional Transport Authority shall not ordinarily refuse to grant an application for permit of any kind made at any time under this Act.
source_instruction: Summarize Section 80 of Motor Vehicles Act, 1988.

instruction: If someone creates a fake government stamp with the intention of using it to forge documents, what punishment can they face according to Section 472?
output: imprisonment for life, or with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to seven years, and shall also be liable to fine
source_instruction: Explain Section 472 (Making or possessing counterfeit seal, etc., with intent to commit forgery punishable under section 467) in simple terms.

instruction: If a Magistrate receives a complaint and decides to hear the case, but then learns that there is an ongoing appeal against the previous decision related to this case, what can the Magistrate do according to Section 343?
output: The Magistrate may, if he thinks fit, at any stage, adjourn the hearing of the case until such appeal is decided.
source_instruction: Explain Section 343 (Procedure of Magistrate taking cognizance) in simple terms.

instruction: If a lower court refuses to file a complaint on someone's behalf under Section 340(1) or (2), can the person who applied for the complaint still appeal?
output: Yes, the person on whose application any Court other than a High Court has refused to make a complaint under Sub-Section (1) or Sub-Section (2) of section 340, or against whom such a complaint has been made by such Court, may appeal to the Court to which such former Court is subordinate.
source_instruction: Explain Section 341 (Appeal) in simple terms.

instruction: If someone enters a house with the intention to steal a valuable item but is caught before they can take anything, what punishment do they face under Section 450 of the Indian Penal Code, 1860?
output: imprisonment of either description for a term not exceeding ten years, and shall also be liable to fine
source_instruction: Explain Section 450 of the Indian Penal Code, 1860.

instruction: If a candidate promises to build a school after winning the election, is this considered bribery under Section 171B of the Indian Penal Code, 1860?
output: No, a declaration of public policy or a promise of public action shall not be an offence under this section.
source_instruction: Explain Section 171B of the Indian Penal Code, 1860.

instruction: If someone is accused of repeatedly damaging public property and claims it was always accidental, can evidence of multiple incidents being part of a pattern be used to show intent?
output: Yes, when there is a question whether an act was accidental or intentional, the fact that such act formed part of a series of similar occurrences, in each of which the person doing the act was concerned, is relevant.
source_instruction: Explain Section 15 of the Indian Evidence Act, 1872.

instruction: If a person sets fire to someone's crop worth Rs. 90, what punishment can they face under Section 435?
output: imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to seven years
source_instruction: Summarize Section 435 of Indian Penal Code, 1860.

instruction: If a charity trust was established for the maintenance of a temple but the temple was destroyed, what action can the court take under Section 92?
output: The Court may alter the original purposes of the express or constructive trust and allow the property or income of such trust or any portion thereof to be applied cy pres in one or more of the following circumstances, namely: (a) where the original purposes of the trust, in whole or in part, cannot be carried out at all, or cannot be carried out according to the directions given in the instrument creating the trust or, where there is no such instrument, according to the spirit of the trust.
source_instruction: Explain Section 92 (Public charities) in simple terms.

instruction: If a charity's original purpose was to build schools in a specific village, but now that village no longer exists, can the charity still continue its activities?
output: Yes, if the original purposes of the charity have either been adequately provided for by other means, or have ceased to be useful or harmful to the community, or have ceased to be charitable, or have ceased to provide a suitable and effective method of using the property available by virtue of the trust, considering the spirit of the trust.
source_instruction: Explain Section 92 (Public charities) in simple terms.

instruction: If an appellant's case is dismissed without hearing them, what conditions must be met according to Section 384?
output: no appeal presented under section 382 shall be dismissed unless the appellant or his pleader has had a reasonable opportunity of being heard in support of the same; no appeal presented under section 383 shall be dismissed except after giving the appellant a reasonable opportunity of being heard in support of the same, unless the Appellate Court considers that the appeal is frivolous or that the production of the accused in custody before the Court would involve such inconvenience as would be disproportionate in the circumstances of the case; no appeal presented under section 383 shall be dismissed summarily until the period allowed for preferring such appeal has expired.
source_instruction: Explain Section 384 (Summary dismissal of appeal) in simple terms.

instruction: If a party missed the original deadline set by the court but applied within 30 days after the deadline passed, can the court still grant an extension?
output: Yes, the court may, in its discretion, from time to time, enlarge such period even though the period originally fixed or granted may have expired, provided the enlargement does not exceed thirty days in total.
source_instruction: What does Section 148 of Code of Civil Procedure, 1908 state?

instruction: If a person brings a 19-year-old girl from abroad to India for marriage, but later she is forced into prostitution, does this action fall under Section 366B?
output: Yes, if the person bringing the girl into India knows or should have known that she would be forced into prostitution, then this action falls under Section 366B as it involves importing a girl under the age of 21 with the intention or likelihood of her being forced into illicit intercourse.
source_instruction: Explain Section 366B (Importation of girl from foreign country) in simple terms.

instruction: If a person fails to appear before the High Court as directed by a bond, what action can the court take according to the given statute?
output: The High Court or Court of Session may direct any Magistrate to levy the amount due on a bond for appearance.
source_instruction: What does Section 450 of Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973 state?

instruction: If a person is acquitted of theft but the court finds out later that they also committed robbery during the same incident, can they be tried for robbery?
output: Yes, a person acquitted or convicted of any offence may be afterwards tried, with the consent of the State Government, for any distinct offence for which a separate charge might have been made against him at the former trial under Sub-Section (1) of section 220.
source_instruction: Explain Section 300 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973.

instruction: If a non-citizen commits an offense on an Indian-registered aircraft while flying over another country, can the offense be investigated and tried in India?
output: Yes, the offense can be dealt with as if it were committed within India where the accused may be found, but with the prior approval of the Central Government.
source_instruction: Explain Section 188 (Offence committed outside India) in simple terms.

instruction: What does the repealed Section 68 of the Code of Civil Procedure, 1908 provide?
output: Section 68 of the Code of Civil Procedure, 1908 provided power to prescribe rules for transferring to collector execution of certain decrees but has been repealed.
source_instruction: Explain Section 68 of the Code of Civil Procedure, 1908.

instruction: If a captain steers a ship too close to a reef and narrowly avoids an accident, but there is potential for harm, what punishment can they face under Section 280 of the Indian Penal Code, 1860?
output: imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to six months, or with fine which may extend to one thousand rupees, or with both
source_instruction: Explain Section 280 of the Indian Penal Code, 1860.

instruction: If a court issues a search warrant based on the belief that a person won't comply with a summons, what can they do next according to Section 93?
output: The court may issue a search warrant. The person to whom such warrant is directed may search or inspect in accordance therewith.
source_instruction: Explain Section 93 (When search-warrant may be issued) in simple terms.

instruction: If a complaint is made in writing, what does the magistrate need to do differently according to Section 200 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973?
output: When the complaint is made in writing, the Magistrate need not examine the complainant and the witnesses.
source_instruction: Summarize Section 200 of Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973.

instruction: If a person claims to have been falsely accused and requests an examination of their body to prove it, what should happen according to Section 54 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973?
output: The Magistrate shall order the examination of the person's body if they allege that such an examination will provide evidence disproving the commission of an offense by them or establishing the commission of an offense by another person.
source_instruction: Summarize Section 54 of Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973.

instruction: If a court declares some property forfeited but cannot prove the source of all its parts, what can the affected person do instead of paying for the whole property?
output: The affected person can choose to pay a fine equivalent to the market value of the unproven part of the property instead of having the entire property forfeited.
source_instruction: Explain Section 105I (Fine in lieu of forfeiture) in simple terms.

instruction: If an email is sent from a sender's computer and received by an addressee's computer, can the court assume that the content of the email matches what was originally entered?
output: Yes, the court may presume that an electronic message, forwarded by the originator through an electronic mail server to the addressee to whom the message purports to be addressed corresponds with the message as fed into his computer for transmission.
source_instruction: What does Section 88A of Indian Evidence Act, 1872 state?

instruction: If a driver's license is revoked under Section 16 of the Motor Vehicles Act, 1988, what additional action can the licensing authority take?
output: require, as a condition of continuing to hold such driving licence, the holder thereof to produce a medical certificate
source_instruction: Summarize Section 16 of Motor Vehicles Act, 1988.

instruction: If an individual wants to obtain a conductor's license, what details should they provide in their application?
output: Every application for a conductor's licence shall be in such form and shall contain such information as may be prescribed.
source_instruction: Explain Section 30 (Grant of conductor's licence) in simple terms.

instruction: If a person reports a crime to a magistrate who does not have jurisdiction over the offense, what should happen according to Section 201?
output: The magistrate should either return the written complaint to the proper court with an endorsement or direct the complainant to the appropriate court if the complaint is not in writing.
source_instruction: Explain Section 201 (Procedure by Magistrate not competent to take cognizance of the case) in simple terms.

instruction: If an accused person confesses to a crime after being promised leniency by a police officer, how would the court determine if the confession is relevant?
output: The court will consider whether the promise of leniency, made by a police officer (a person in authority), was sufficient to give the accused reasonable grounds to believe that it influenced their decision to make the confession.
source_instruction: Summarize Section 24 of Indian Evidence Act, 1872.

instruction: If a person is sentenced to death by a High Court and appeals to the Supreme Court, how long will their sentence be postponed?
output: The sentence will be postponed until the period allowed for preferring such appeal has expired, or if an appeal is preferred within that period, until such appeal is disposed of by the Supreme Court.
source_instruction: Explain Section 415 (Postponement of execution of sentence of death in case of appeal to Supreme Court) in simple terms.

instruction: If a driver is found to have 40 mg of alcohol in their blood, can they be charged under Section 185 of the Motor Vehicles Act, 1988?
output: Yes, if the driver's blood alcohol level exceeds 30 mg per 100 ml of blood, they can be charged under Section 185 of the Motor Vehicles Act, 1988.
source_instruction: Explain Section 185 (Driving by a drunken person or by a person under the influence of drugs) in simple terms.

instruction: Can the Central Government make rules regarding the production of licenses and certificates to police officers under Section 130 of the Motor Vehicles Act, 1988?
output: Yes, the Central Government can make rules regarding the manner in which the licences and certificates may be produced to the police officer under section 130.
source_instruction: What does Section 137 of Motor Vehicles Act, 1988 state?

instruction: If an accused raises a point of law during their defense arguments, what can the prosecution do according to Section 234?
output: The prosecution may, with the permission of the Judge, make its submissions with regard to such point of law.
source_instruction: Explain Section 234 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973.

instruction: If there is an act specifically dealing with the punishment of mutiny among soldiers, how does Section 5 of the Indian Penal Code, 1860 treat such an act?
output: Section 5 of the Indian Penal Code, 1860 does not affect the provisions of any Act for punishing mutiny among soldiers.
source_instruction: Explain Section 5 of the Indian Penal Code, 1860.

instruction: If a couple wants to dissolve their marriage under the Indian Divorce Act, 1869, what is the first step they should take?
output: any husband or wife may present a petition to the District Court
source_instruction: Summarize Section 18 of Indian Divorce Act, 1869.

instruction: If a mother applies for maintenance on behalf of her minor child, who should receive a copy of the order under Section 128 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973?
output: The person in whose favour the order is made, which in this case would be the minor child, or their guardian if any, should receive a copy of the order without payment.
source_instruction: Summarize Section 128 of Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973.

instruction: If someone sets fire to a building with the intention to cause damage, what kind of punishment can they face according to Section 438?
output: imprisonment for life. or with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.
source_instruction: Explain Section 438 (Punishment for the mischief described in section 437 committed by fire or explosive substance) in simple terms.

instruction: If a woman has been granted an order of maintenance but her ex-husband fails to pay, what can she do according to Section 128 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973?
output: She can obtain a copy of the order of maintenance free of cost and present it to any Magistrate in the area where her ex-husband resides. The Magistrate can then enforce the order upon being satisfied about the identity of the parties and the non-payment of the maintenance amount.
source_instruction: Explain Section 128 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973.

instruction: If someone knows that a soldier has left his post without permission and decides to hide him in their house, what punishment can they face under Section 136?
output: imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to two years, or with fine or with both
source_instruction: Explain Section 136 (Harbouring deserter) in simple terms.

instruction: If a husband overhears a conversation between his wife and another person while they are together, can he be forced to testify about what he heard?
output: No, under Section 122 of the Indian Evidence Act, 1872, a person who is or has been married cannot be compelled to disclose any communication made to them by their spouse during marriage.
source_instruction: What does Section 122 of Indian Evidence Act, 1872 state?

instruction: If someone brings in fake coins from another country but believes they are real, what punishment can they face under Section 237 of the Indian Penal Code, 1860?
output: imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to three years, and shall also be liable to fine
source_instruction: Summarize Section 237 of Indian Penal Code, 1860.

instruction: If a promissory note is dishonoured and the holder incurs Rs. 500 in presenting, noting, and protesting the instrument, what is the total compensation the holder can claim from the drawer?
output: the holder is entitled to the amount due upon the instrument, together with the expenses properly incurred in presenting, noting and protesting it; when the person charged resides at a place different fr
source_instruction: Summarize Section 117 of Negotiable Instruments Act, 1881.

instruction: If a 17-year-old girl is raped, who can file a complaint on her behalf?
output: where such person is under the age of eighteen years, or is an idiot or a lunatic, or is from sickness or infirmity unable to make a complaint, or is a woman who, according to the local customs and manners, ought not to be compelled to appear in public, some other person may, with the leave of the Court, make a complaint on his or her behalf
source_instruction: What does Section 198 of Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973 state?

instruction: If a man has sexual intercourse with his wife who is under 15 years old, can the police file charges after more than one year has passed?
output: No, the police cannot file charges under section 376 of the Indian Penal Code if more than one year has elapsed since the offense occurred.
source_instruction: What does Section 198 of Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973 state?

instruction: If someone leaves their garbage on the sidewalk causing a foul smell and attracting pests, can they be charged under Section 268 of the Indian Penal Code, 1860?
output: Yes, if leaving the garbage on the sidewalk causes a common injury, danger or annoyance to the public or people in the vicinity, then the person could be considered guilty of a public nuisance as per Section 268 of the Indian Penal Code, 1860.
source_instruction: Explain Section 268 of the Indian Penal Code, 1860.

instruction: If a Chief Judicial Magistrate takes cognizance of an offense, under which circumstances can they transfer the case to another Magistrate?
output: A Chief Judicial Magistrate can transfer the case to any competent Magistrate subordinate to him after taking cognizance of an offense.
source_instruction: Explain Section 192 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973.

instruction: If an accused person is called as a witness in their own criminal case, what conditions must be met according to Section 315 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973?
output: He shall not be called as a witness except on his own request in writing; his failure to give evidence shall not be made the subject of any comment by any of the parties or the Court or give rise to any presumption against himself or any person charged together with him at the same trial.
source_instruction: Explain Section 315 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973.

instruction: If someone sells an obscene book to a 17-year-old, what punishment can they face?
output: On first conviction, the punishment is imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to three years, and with fine which may extend to two thousand rupees. In the event of a second or subsequent conviction, the punishment is imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to seven years, and also with fine which may extend to five thousand rupees.
source_instruction: Explain Section 293 (Sale, etc., of obscene objects to young person) in simple terms.

instruction: If the central government wants to exempt a new type of electric scooter from the Motor Vehicles Act, 1988, what is required according to Section 2B?
output: The central government may exempt certain types of mechanically propelled vehicles from the application of the provisions of this Act in order to promote innovation, research and development in the fields of vehicular engineering, mechanically propelled vehicles and transportation in general.
source_instruction: Explain Section 2B of the Motor Vehicles Act, 1988.

instruction: If a person applies for a private service vehicle permit to operate a bus with a seating capacity of 20 seats, what details must they provide in their application?
output: The application for a permit to use a motor vehicle as a private service vehicle shall contain the following particulars, namely: (a) type and seating capacity of the vehicle; (b) the area or the route or routes to which the application relates; (c) the manner in which it is claimed that the purpose of carrying persons otherwise than for hire or reward or in connection with the trade or business carried on by the applicant will be served by the vehicle; and (d) any other particulars which may be prescribed.
source_instruction: What does Section 76 of Motor Vehicles Act, 1988 state?

instruction: If a vehicle's registration was suspended for 7 months, can the registering authority cancel its registration?
output: Yes, because the suspension of registration has continued without interruption for a period of not less than six months.
source_instruction: What does Section 54 of Motor Vehicles Act, 1988 state?

instruction: If a Sessions Judge receives a report from a lower court suggesting a case should be transferred, what can the Sessions Judge do according to Section 408?
output: The Sessions Judge may order that any particular case be transferred from one Criminal Court to another Criminal Court in his sessions division.
source_instruction: Explain Section 408 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973.

instruction: If a court convicts an accused of a non-cognizable offense and orders them to pay costs to the complainant, what happens if the accused fails to pay?
output: in default of payment, the accused shall suffer simple imprisonment for a period not exceeding thirty days
source_instruction: Summarize Section 359 of Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973.

instruction: If a person is charged with multiple offenses and convicted of one, can the remaining charges still be pursued if the original prosecutor decides to drop them?
output: Yes, if the original prosecutor decides to drop the remaining charges with the consent of the court, those charges will be withdrawn and considered as an acquittal unless the initial conviction is set aside by the court.
source_instruction: Explain Section 224 (Withdrawal of remaining charges on conviction on one of several charges) in simple terms.

instruction: If a police officer finds sufficient evidence after investigating a crime, what should they do with the accused?
output: Such officer shall forward the accused under custody to a Magistrate empowered to take cognizance of the offence upon a police report and to try the accused or commit him for trial, or, if the offence is bailable and the accused is able to give security, shall take security from him for his appearance before such Magistrate on a day fixed and for his attendance from day to day before such Magistrate until otherwise directed.
source_instruction: What does Section 170 of Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973 state?

instruction: What punishment can be given to someone who abets another's suicide according to Section 306 of the Indian Penal Code, 1860?
output: imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine
source_instruction: Explain Section 306 of the Indian Penal Code, 1860.

instruction: If a person sues for a dishonored cheque and produces a protest, what presumption does the court make?
output: The court shall presume the fact of dishonour, unless and until such fact is disproved.
source_instruction: Explain Section 119 (Presumption on proof of protest) in simple terms.

instruction: If two brothers sue each other over the ownership of a property, and the case is dismissed due to lack of jurisdiction, can they file another lawsuit on the same matter later?
output: No, if the matter of ownership of the property was directly and substantially in issue in the first lawsuit, then according to Section 11 of the Code of Civil Procedure, 1908, the second lawsuit would be barred because the issue has already been heard and finally decided by a court, even though the court lacked jurisdiction.
source_instruction: Explain Section 11 (Res judicata) in simple terms.

instruction: If a person commits three thefts in one year, can they all be charged together under the same section?
output: Yes, if the three thefts committed in one year are of the same kind, they can be charged together under Section 219 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973.
source_instruction: Under which Act does Section 219 titled 'Three offences of same kind within year may be charged together' fall?

instruction: If a case is brought before an Additional Chief Metropolitan Magistrate, under whose authority can decisions be appealed?
output: Decisions made by an Additional Chief Metropolitan Magistrate can be appealed under the general control of the Sessions Judge.
source_instruction: What does Section 19 of Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973 state?

instruction: If a suspect makes a written statement to a police officer during an investigation, can the police use this statement as evidence in court?
output: No, the statement made by any person to a police officer in the course of an investigation under this Chapter, if reduced to writing, cannot be signed by the person making it and cannot be used for any purpose, save as hereinafter provided, at any inquiry or trial in respect of any offence under investigation at the time when such statement was made.
source_instruction: Explain Section 162 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973.

instruction: If a case involves identifying the authorship of a painting, which type of expert's opinion would be considered relevant under Section 45 of the Indian Evidence Act, 1872?
